    2012-11-29: When you finally get this amCase Hybird Bumper Case on it is not going to stretch out, slip or fall off. It took some effort to get it on trying to stretch the last corner of the case on my iPhone 5, but once I got it on it fit like a glove. The cut outs lined up perfectly and the volume raised buttons hit the iPhones buttons without a glitch. The soft rubber sides made a good contact with the inside of my hand, so no need to worry if it will slide out. However, the back of the case is made out of a thinner hard plastic which has a slipperier finish. This is a hard and soft case - the sides are soft rubber, but the back is made of a hardened plastic, I guess that is where the term Hybird comes in.I was sent this case for free directly from the manufacturer to try out, and in return all they asked for was an honest review. I am happy to say I am pleased with the amCase Hybird Bumper Case. It is slim, lightweight and using it with a screen protector it will definitely protect your iPhone 5 from scratches.

I'm not worried about damaging the phone at all taking the case on and off.The phone feels thin with the case on. I can't tell if the case is on or off with the phone in my pocket. At the price point the case is a great value, and you won't be kicking yourself if you happen to not like it in person. I will be using it even after purchasing something bulkier because I still want the thinner feel sometimes, and it's nice being able to see the back of my white Nexus 5.

    2013-12-15: This was one of the first cases I purchased for my iPhone 5, close to release day.     Rating: 5

    2014-01-12: First off, the fitment is PERFECT. Slips on very securely, no loose areas, and cut-outs are right on and good-sized. I would have paid $25 for this case and still been happy with my purchase.Protection: If you're the type who *needs* an otterbox, the stop reading and buy one of those. However, if you're looking for the BEST protection you can get in a slim, attractive case, this is it! This case (like most TPU cases) adds a nice lip around the screen to protect the edges from impacts, and allow you to place the phone face-down without anything touching the screen.Appearance: The combination of hard-plastic transparent back and gloss TPU bumper works well for my white Nexus 5. The two halves are mated perfectly, no glue or rough edges. Only minor negative is the amCase logo printed on the back.I also used the Anker 3-pack screen protectors, which are a static-cling style, and the case didn't interfere with it at all.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-12: This case is definitely a good by for the money. Its a bumper style case with a frosted see through back. My only complaint is that the rubber round the sides gets a little slippery. check out a review on this case, link will be in the comments.

    Rating: 3

    2014-06-09: Can't get much better than this for the money. Looks great, lets me see my beautiful HTC One M8, and provides nice protection to boot. Excellent and very friendly customer service, too. Great company and product!

    2014-04-23: Great case and for a really great price .bought it in a hardbeat. u guys would love this case if you want Slim profile with good grip

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-26: Case is very form fitting, went out snug but without feeling like it's going to tear your iphone up. The case is semi-smoke clear on the back, and is very slippy for easy pocket access. Overall, no complaints thus far, and will probably buy another case from this brand. Their amFilm is great for a screen protector, and the case is great for a slim iPhone 5 case, so I'm impressed so far.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-29: This case is a great way to protect your phone bumper style.The design of this case is very straight forward, but effective.The back of the case is a hard but has a little bit of give and made of polycarbonate (hard plastic). It does a great job protecting the phone from impact. There are cutouts for the camera/flash, heart rate sensor, and speaker.The side of the case is made of TPU, and feels like a stiff silicone rubber mix. There are cutouts for the headphone jack, charging port, and IR blaster. Also, there are button overlays for the volume and power buttons. The sides take on the role of a bumper and helps stop dents and dings.In the hand, the case is very light and does not add any noticeable weight. Once on the phone, the case has a nice tight fit and protects the phone quite nicely. There is also a small raised edge on the front of the case so your phone can be placed faced down without scratching your screen.If you are looking for a case to protect your phone, give these a try. The best part is that it can't be beat for the price.CONTENTS:amCase Hybrid Bumper CaseFEATURES:Case Back Material: PolycarbonateCase Side Material: TPU (Thermoplastic Polyurethane)Warranty: 1 YearGuarantee: 30-Day Money BackI was supplied a sample for the purpose of review.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-21: I just got my amCASE hybrid case and I'm quite pleased with it! First time buying an amCASE case but definitely won't be my last time.PackagingOne thing I like to see with packaging is when its kept to a minimum. It's more eco-friendly and it keeps cost down for the manufacturer and consumer. We don't need a flashy package do we? They spend the money were it belongs, on the product!Build Quality/DesignThe build quality seems to be high. No rough corners, sharp edges or defects. All lines are clean and well made. It does have a white "amCASE" logo on the back that doesn't seem to quite fit with everything else but it's not too noticeable or distracting. They went with a two tone two material hybrid design. The back is a harder frosted plastic while the sides are a glossy tpu rubber material. It transitions from on material to the other seemlessly.The frosted back is transparent but gives a smoked/blurry effect when looking through it. Which I kinda like; sort of artsy don't you say?All cutouts seem to be perfectly aligned. No ports are covered. I like how they went with a big cutout for the micro usb port so we can use any micro usb cable to charge our phones. Also the cutout for the headphone jack is decently big. Would like it to be a tad bigger so ANY headphone plug can be used but it looks like most if not all plugs would be okay with this case. I hate it when a cases headphone cutout is too small to use with your headphones but that wasn't the case with this one.The "buttons" on the case to simulate where the actually buttons are of not the best quality but definitely not the worst I've seen on tpu cases. Finding the buttons in pocket wasn't a problem as it has a good feel to them. Pressing them was good also. I never felt like I had to exert too much effort to get the button press to register with the phone.It's also worth mentioning that the edges are raised to prevent scratching the phone when placing it face down on a table.It's not the slimmest nor the bulkiest but a good compromise between the two. It won't protect your phone from a drop 2 stories up but it will provide good protection all the way around your phone for those minor drops we all have.

Overall, for the price this is a great case that I will keep using. My few issues with the device are that the buttons are stiff so they require a little more force to press than I would hope. Also, while the micro USB port is larger than some cases I have used, I do still have issues with some cables (not the official) that have large micro USB connectors. The cables will fit in and charge the device, but if are moved or pulled even the slightest will stop charging. Again, the stock connector works fine, but some brands of cables (like Amazon Basic) have larger connectors.

    2014-01-09: This case is the most comfortable case I've found for the Nexus 5. It's smooth and fits the curves of the Nexus 5, unlike many other cases from Spigen. It's also very thin, but seems like it would provide good protection in an event of a drop. It's got a great balance between grippy and smooth, allowing you adequate grip while holding it, and slippery enough to pull out of your pocket with ease. Overall, It's a great value.There is one large issue I have with this case that's preventing me from using it. I have a glass screen protector from Spigen on my Nexus 5 and this case pushes on it and lifts it. If I did not have a screen protector on my phone, I would be using this one over the 4 other cases I've tried (Spigen Ultra hybrid, Neo Hybrid, Slim Armor, Ballistic. My brother has the N5 also, so we got a lot of cases between the two of us.)Another issue which is less important is that the case has a logo on the back in white that says amCase, it's not very pleasing to look at, specially on the black Nexus 5. I would've preferred they do some etching on the side or made it more discreet. The lettering does wear and becomes less obnoxious after a little while. Going to probably take some nail polish remover to it when I'm bored.*updated* I gave the case another shot since I like it a lot and am happy to say that it hasn't pulled on my screen protector since the week I've put it back on. Not sure if it wasn't totally on correctly the first time or what but it's still something to be wary of. I'm going to be leaving this case on and not fiddle with it and update it if it ends up breaking the screen protector.

    2013-11-23: This case is holding up well, and seems to have compatibility with their amFilm Premium Screen Protector Film HD Clear (Invisible) I bought with it. Port cutouts are well done, and the rear panel is thick enough to keep the camera lens from protruding through its opening, letting me lay the phone rear-down on a flat surface with confidence.I have only minor detractions on this case that kept me from giving a 5 star rating. One, the buttons feel a bit mushy and lack the satisfying click when using the power/sleep button or the volume rocker.     Rating: 5

    2011-10-23: I went to the Verizon Store and other big box retailers and literally took every iPhone4(s) case out of the box and tested it on my new phone. The advantage to this dual case from Incipio is that it comes in a variety of different color combinations and you're able to get two contrasting colors (white/gray looks really good on a white iPhone). The inner silicone case goes on very easily, but provides minimal support and feels exactly like a balloon that hasn't been inflated. The case covers some of the buttons on the side, but it is still easy enough to press them.The outer case provides some much needed protection and it slides right on over the silicone inner layer. The sliding on wasn't as easy as I was anticipating and once in place you can see a few spots where the outer layer does not provide any protection (top/bottom). Once both layers are in place the phone has a nice sturdy feel without having too much bulk added.Overall this is a decent case, but there were better options out there from Belkin and Case Mate that only had one hard outer layer that felt sturdier and was easier to put on and take off. You could use just the outer layer of this case without the inner silicone, but I wouldn't recommend solely using the inner layer.

    Rating: 3

    2013-08-13: I've used this line of case since I bought my iPhone 4s. I love the fact that it covers your whole phone including the buttons with holes just big enough for the camera and speaker/microphone. The silicone sleeve comes around over the edge of the screen so it adds protection if you place the phone face down. I did drop my phone from about desk high onto my hardwood floor and the case broke in the corner but it protected my phone perfectly. I've gone through two cases this way but replacing them is a lot cheaper than replacing the phone.

    Rating: 5

    2012-01-05: I've had this case since the first week of November 2011. I bought it for a new iPhone 4S. I must say, this is one of the best cases I've ever owned for a phone. I've bought everything from the cheapest cases to the most expensive for past phones. One of the most expensive cases I've ever owned was a Droid case that started out okay but literally fell apart at the seams after a few months. This case is holding up very well. It's a silicone case, so if you're particularly rough or harsh on your phone, expect fast wear and tear. I use my iPhone regularly but I'm careful with it and never beat it up or throw it around as I've seen a lot of others do. Not only do my phones look the same at the end of my contract as they did the day I bought them, but cases last pretty good as well. So for that expensive case to fail, it really must have been rubbish. This affordable case on the other hand, is not rubbish and fits the phone like a glove. It offers a stylish non-slip gripping surface, and all buttoins, cameras, and openings have perfect cut-outs. Nothing is obstructed, not even partially. My 4S fits perfect. The only intentionally covered buttons are the volume buttons and power button. The thickness and flexibility of the case is just right, allowing me to easily push the buttons whenever needed, even without looking. The bottom of the scase is cut so perfectly, it allows my iphone to fit on my speaker dock without removing the case. Now that is a major plus. I mainly carry the phone in my pocket and occassionally some lint will intrude, but it's nothing a can of spray air and a quick wipe with a cloth can't fix. If anything gets really bad or a lot of debris finds its way into the case, the case is easily removable for cleaning or whatever the need may be. I am very happy with this case and very satisfied with my purchase. This has become my new iPhone case of choice. And the price only makes it better.

  • B004P8JL76

    $B004P8JL76

    2011-09-15: Excellent basic phone. Excellent reception, call quality and battery life. It's a steal at this price. It has good looks even though it may not look so good in the picture.This phone is a quadband phone which means you can use it across the globe. The fact it doesn't have 3g is not a problem for calling or receiving. The call clarity or reception don't decrease because of that. The keyboard is awesome. We have a Nokia E5, but when compared to that, this phone's keyboard is far better and the phone itself is very sturdy and gives a good feeling when holding to your ears (you might have noticed that some phones really don't feel well near the ears).We have an Android touchphone too. Touching, sliding and tapping to receive calls or dial call is a pain. It's a shame that this whole world is bent on features forgetting the basic functionality of the phone which is calling and receiving calls. It's so disappointing there are not many non-smart phones with good reception and call quality. And there are fewer flip phone with those qualities.Added in June 2012:This phone is going steady. We have two phones and one is being used by my teenage son. He has dropped it at least twenty times in front of me (imagine how many times he would have dropped when I was not there!), but it continues to work without any issues. He has a hard cover for the phone but most of the times when he dropped it, the cover, battery cover and battery will fall apart. But it will always work after putting them together. Once he lost it while walking on the footpath when it was snowing and got it only after a couple of hours. I immediately switched it off, removed the battery and let it dry for a day. And it worked again! I hope and pray Nokia will continue to manufacture good quality dumb phones like this.

    Rating: 4

    2014-02-01: If you are looking for no compromises and need the maximum protection for your Note 3, stepping up to Kraken AMS is the way to go. With triple layer of protection this case can withstand a very high level of abuse, and it has been tested to Military Standards to meet or exceed MIL-STD-810L requirements. What makes it so tough? Let's take a closer look.Just like all other Trident cases, it arrived in a box with a clear front display and a full view of the case where the back of the box had details of all the features. The side of the box also includes icons of available AMS attachments. AMS is actually stands for Adaptive Modular System which enables various attachments/accessories to be connected to the back of the outer exoskeleton shell. The case design starts with an inner soft silicon shell, which is actually sold by itself as Perseus AMS case for Note 3. This is a light duty soft sleeve case which you can use as standalone for the occasions when you need just a minimal scratch and bump protection. Once you are ready for a more serious protection, you place Perseus AMS case into a heavy duty exoskeleton shell made out of hardened PC material with reinforced TPE corners. The same TPE material is used to fully seal power and volume buttons (still allowing an easy access and tactile response), and to protect with flexible port covers headphone, micro-usb, and s-pen ports. This outer shell also features a loop for lanyard to add more security when handling this case outdoors, and opening for sliding AMS accessories. The TPE corners also work as skid pads to prevent case from sliding across the surface.In order to enhance screen protection of your Note 3, Kraken AMS adds a front frame with an attached screen protector, similar to Cyclops series model. This adds an ultimate screen scratch protection and seals the screen for use in a light rain, dust, or wind. It doesn't make this case waterproof since you still have openings for home buttons, speaker, camera and notification light, but it gives you a piece of mind if you need to use your phone or take a call outside when elements of nature are not in your favor. As part of AMS system, you get one of the accessories bundled with a case - multimedia kickstand. Solid metal construction, its a nice interlocking kickstand for landscape/portrait positioning of your phone to enjoy watching a movie or YT video, etc. In addition, this Kraken AMS case also comes with a unique belt clip holster. We all know how big Note 3 is to begin with, so using an even bigger holster would add more bulk to carry on your belt clip. Here, Trident came up with a minimal design approach of a slim holster bracket with a clip that can rotate 360 degree and securely attaches to the front of your phone/case.Overall, this is one tough case to consider if you are looking for a serious protection for your Note 3 and would like to have flexibility of either slimming it down or adding more options as part of it's modular system.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-13: Beware if you order this case, because you might end up with this one, because I’m sending it back! I thought it would be safe to buy a case that is fulfilled by Amazon…I thought my odds of getting ripped off would be less likely. Not this time! This case was not only opened and used…it must have been returned and re-sold in faulty condition. First, the container arrived dirty, tattered, and half open. I took the case out and noticed the rubber bumpers were dirty. I looked closer and the screen protector looked like it was pushed in and it there were smudges all over it, and there’s a crease in the screen protector near the home button. I opened the case and there was hair and/or sting-like stuff on the inside of the screen protector part of the case. The belt-clip is a flimsy piece of s***. Finally, the kick-stand doesn't stay closed. It just flops in and out. This case has obviously been used. The one good thing I can say about this case is that it truly looks tough…like it can take a beating. Unfortunately, this case has already taken a beaten. I CANNOT ACCEPT THIS! It must go back. If I had owned this for 6-months and it looked like this…fine. But I cannot accept this looking this way brand new straight out of the box. No way. I paid $12 for a cheap rugged case for my son, and it’s a way better deal than this!

    2010-01-15: After reading the reviews, I decided that I'd get a charging pod although I felt that I had no real need for it. If you have a gel skin, you'll have to remove it so it can charge.Charging your Bold just by the Micro USB cable is fine, but if you want to go for aesthetics and also reduce the wear on your Micro USB port, this is a great solution for you.     2013-02-20: The advertising says this charger is specifically for the Samsung Galaxy SIII which is what I own. I have used this battery charger several times. It works as it should. It has a nice feature - a large lighted bar indicating the status of the charge. The light is red until the battery is fully charged. Once charging is complete the light changes to blue. I also used this charger to charge both my battery and my phone via the USB outlet on the charger. Both battery and phone charged successfully. If you intend to charge your phone at night but light disturbs your sleep I would recommend plugging the device in somewhere out of your line of sight as the light shows brightly in the dark. I did have an initial concern. The battery for my S3 is wider than the charger. It does not fit snuggly into the charger. I was concerned that the weight of the battery would cause it to fall out of the charger. This didn't happen but it was and is still a concern.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-25: Product works great. Per the battery manufacturers' instruction, train your batteries. Let them fully discharge, and then leave them in the charger for a couple of additional hours after the charger indicates they are recharged. Do this for 3-5 cycles. This is no rapid charger. It takes about 8hrs to charge a standard 2100mAh battery. Have not tried it on the extended battery yet - but it will fit both. The green key ring was a nice tchotchke.

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-20: Not the fastest charger in the world, but at least give me peace of mind that it's not cooking my batteries when it's charging them. Nicely done...

    Rating: 4

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-15: I bought this stand for my Samsung Note 3. My phone is in a Ballistic Jewel Protective case, and it sets in the stand with plenty of room to spare. If you have a thicker more protective case, like an Otterbox, this would still work as advertised. I am able to use this stand during charging. There is plenty of room in the middle of the base for the charger to be inserted while standing vertically. You will have to bend your charging cord a bit at first so that it sits or lays right in the stand, but that is not a big deal. I bought two! One for my nightstand, and one for my table downstairs. It is very useful! I prefer using this so I can see my screen, instead of just having it flat on a table and needing to pick it up to look at it. Lazy, I know (: Great price, and cool gadget!

    2014-03-07: This is a nice stand. It is made of a rubber that is hard to clean and is flat black. It is also hollow inside so I stock two different charging cables in the hollow cavity & cut a wire clothes hanger & drilled a hole in the bottom section to hold the cables in, that works perfect. That way one can just pick it up and place the phone on it and run the charging cable to it either in the vertical or horizonal position. In the vertical position I use one of the flat instead of a round cable and it works perfect to run under this stand & connect the phone. I don't leave it hooked up since I have a regular charging dock which is taped to the desk. This is made of a rubber than prevents it from moving around also. Holds iPhones, iPads very well. Simple and user friendly stand. It would be great for kids since they could even walk and sit on it and not hurt it.

  • B00CIF9MJK

    $B00CIF9MJK

    2014-07-18: I loved my Samsung Galaxy Proclaim, but when I got my new S4, it blew my mind. The screen is so amazing that it honestly hurt my eyes a little for the first hour or so (in the same way that a new glasses prescription hurts - your brain is getting so much more visual information than it's used to, so it needs a minute to adjust). As a teacher, one of my favorite features is S-Beam. S-Beam allows you to send a file to another Samsung phone, just by tapping the two phones back-to-back. When I need to give each of my students a copy of a handout, I no longer need to print one for each student. I print copies for those without Samsungs, but for those students who have Samsungs, I just walk around the room and "bump" the file to each of them.In case anyone reading this has read that sometimes when you order a phone online, what arrives is a knockoff, I will say that when I got my phone, I checked all of the tell tale signs for knockoff S4's and the phone I received is definitely authentic.

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-03: Got it on time and of course LOOOVE the the phone itself , Works just perfect and i hope there will be no issues with it . Thank you again , and will shop with this seller again

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-25: I've been waiting for this phone for months, while also planning on switching carriers at the same time. Here's what I like about the phone:Beautiful screen - for those of us who don't have perfect vision, this screen is very readable. The fonts are an appropriate size, with good contrast.Nice speed. The screen is responsive, and allows multiple windows to be open at once.Screen size: For certain apps, I.e. the kindle app, this screen approximates an e-reader very well (as opposed to reading on a smaller phone screen.)The interface is very thoughtfully designed. Great job, Samsung! Unobtrusive, noninvasive methods of accessing critical apps are available from almost anyplace on the phone.Icons/graphics are adorable, and creatively designed. No boring manila folders on this phone! Your folders show contents from the outside of the folder... Cute.Ease of use: There is a little bit of a learning curve on this phone (I had the Samsung Epic previously), but I've pretty much figured it out in a few hours. It's going to be great. Once you get the hang of the graphics, it's really quick to move things around, personalize, etc.It really blurs the boundary between a tablet and a phone, without becoming too huge, like the Note (which I am now glad I did not buy).Voice quality: I'd read reviews in the last few days that state that it is not very good... I think it's fine. The sound is clear, and volume is fine.One of my favorite apps for Android: Out of Milk. Running out of groceries? Scan the bar code into one of your shopping lists, (or input by voice or typing), and your shopping list is complete. I keep a running shopping list for Trader Joes, and my other local market. When I go to the store, I simply move the items I need to the top of the list, and go for it! No more paper lists!One heads up: (carrier, not phone related): check on Visual Voicemail.... I use it all the time, and really like it. I was surprised to discover that I had to pay for it as an add on with Verizon.... It was part of my Sprint service previously.** UPDATE **I've had the phone for almost a week, and it's simply a PLEASURE to use! Lots of nice touches: pop up asking if you'd like to add someone to your contacts after a call from a non contact, for example.Camera: is great. I photographed an entire exhibit in a museum.... No flash, in dark rooms, and the photos are stunning.Battery life: surprisingly good! I used the phone all day yesterday, on and off trains where it would have been seeking service in tunnels (usually drains battery quicker), used my Kindle app, made calls, sent texts and emails, and I still had 60% at the end of a ten hour day.Battery recharging: using the charging cord that comes with the phone, it charges in no time... A couple of hours at most. I've been amazed at the recharge speed, compared to my previous phone.Kindle app is like a baby Kindle... there's just enough on the page to not feel like you are only reading a few sentences at a time like on some smaller devices.I'm so pleased with my choice, I hope you enjoy it, also.(And in case this is helpful to anyone: if you are debating about a case, I have the Seidio holster case... Please see my review.)*************Enjoy this great device! Questions? Drop a note, and I'll get back to you.

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-22: My daughter loved her Christmas present this year. But, I paid top dollar and wished I had waited a week or two. Prices dropped after Christmas.

    Rating: 5

    2012-04-26: This case was very appealing to me since I have been a fan of gameboy since it debuted, and for only a couple dollars I decided why not! You can clearly see the seam from the machine, but again it was only 2 dollars. The gameboy detail is actually very well made, I originally assumed that it might be a print, but actually there are raised buttons and "gameboy screen". This case fits well and all ports and openings are accessible. However, the camera cut out provides a lot of flash back, and the long sides seem to be stretched out. All in all for two dollars it's a fun case to have and show your friends, also will provide adequate protection when having a night out on the town.

  • B009G5T9LG

    $B009G5T9LG

    2013-05-02: I previously reviewed Belkin's iPod armband and sadly I have very similar reservations with regards to the iPhone armband. The material is unfortunate. It gets soaked when sweaty and it actually slides down my arm, which is a distraction while running and even a hindrance to my overall run. The same issues with regards to the plastic casing are here, in that it can be hard to work the phone through the case. Like I've mentioned in my review of the iPod armband, I basically hit shuffle on my playlist and hit the road, but with my phone there are times when I need to answer the phone, and so I need to be able to access the phone through the casing. My biggest issue here though is the fact that the slot for the phone is so snug that it will not fit my phone unless I take the phone case off. This is annoying, especially since I have one of those cases that is hard to take apart. To top it all off, the design on this armband is CHEAP looking. It looks terrible, and I know that looks aren't everything, but if the performance is bad and the look is bad then the product has no redeeming qualities.

    Rating: 1

    2013-05-15: I've long needed a better armband for my gym workouts and the Belkin Pro-Fit Armband for iPhone 5 is definitely better than what I had been using previously.I'm actually using it for an iPhone 4 and it fits (a bit snug at first), provided I first remove my phone from its protective case. It might be different if I used it for jogging, but for my gym needs (cardio and weights) it does what it needs to do. I don't have the biggest biceps in the world but I've had no problems with it slipping once the clasp closure was adjusted. And yes, as some of the other reviews have noted, the nylon backing gets pretty sweaty but because the inside is rubber-coated, the phone itself remains dry.The protective plastic screen, on the other hand, makes using your phone's touchscreen admittedly tricky but not impossible--during my workouts I only really need to access it for the music apps.All in all, it's easy to see where there would be room for improvement in subsequent versions, but, for my needs, it's still a more comfortable fit than my old armband.

    Rating: 3

    2013-05-14: The way that it fits your arm is actually pretty interesting. The clip mechanism does make it easier to fit it into place than some other armbands I've tried in the past. Resizing it isn't terribly difficult. The material against your skin seems to be a wicking fabric that doesn't really provide a waterproof space, though shouldn't be an issue unless you're sweating extremely profusely.The actual iPhone compartment seems like it could've been shaped just a little better. The plastic over the screen sticks out in a way that makes the touch screen a little harder to use than it needs to be.It basically gets the job done, but it has enough minor issues that it's tough to say I'd enthusiastically recommend it over other options. They all seem to have their ups and downs (at least the ones I've tried out).

    Rating: 3

    2013-04-29: Previous versions of this Armband, of which I've had a couple, had a velcro assembly. This one has a traditional bracket/buckle approach which actually feels less secure and, because of the buckle, is more bulky. Granted, the phone is bulky, but this adds to it and helps load up more weight on one side of your upper body.Further, addressing other review, I wanted to address just a couple things, more unique to me than anything:1. First, though, I've read that it doesn't hold the iPhone5. It does. Now, technically, the iPhone5 goes in upside down (there's a camera hole at the bottom of the inset, ostensibly to show you how to align the device). This makes the iPhone completely snug in the slot. However, it is upside down. That's necessary if you are using earphones (the plug for that is at the bottom of the phone). I suppose that if you didn't put it on your arm upside down, the slot would be at the bottom, not the top, and you would worry that it would slide out. I don't know if that's an issue, but it's definitely not an issue if you use the band as intended.2. I thought I might use this for the GPS capability on my phone. I don't listen to music when I run. However, the tightness and the jostling when running a fair distance (7 miles) left burn marks and cuts on my arm. I'll wear it over a shirt in the winter, but overall, this makes the buckle thing even more of a pain, because it will take more time to adjust it based on the shirt I'm wearing.Overall, I recommend, theBelkin EaseFit Armband For New Apple iPhone 5 (Black). My daughter has kidnapped that one and I'm hoping to convince her to trade....

    Rating: 3

    2013-06-27: Even on it smallest size, the arm band was too large for my arm. I am average in arm size and thin but nowhere near skinny .the material was very comfortable and i like that its waterproof.however, it didn't allow for enough stretch to put the phone in easily and took an extended amount of time to get the phone situated in the band.not very convenient, but once in it was fine.The shield flap on top was a brilliant idea with the magnetic strip, love that feature!Would recommend to someone with m-l arms.Overall , it is a good deal for the vast majority !!

    2013-07-18: This is a decent armband for those of you who use your iPhone during workouts. It keeps the phone snug and secure, as well as protected from drops and sweat. The phone is easy to slip and out of the band as needed. The only complaint I could really make is that you cannot have on another case on your iPhone when fitting it into this band.     Rating: 4

    2013-06-20: I'm a walker/runner and get really tired of having to hold my phone, so I was very excited to try the Belkin Pro-Fit Arm Band. Overall, I feel it works as described. I noticed some people complained that it was too tight, but I've got mine as tight as it will go and kind of wish I could make it a bit tighter. I find that when I first start walking/running, I'm tugging it back up my arm because the material is very smooth. I kind of wish it was a little tacky so it would stay put, but once I start moving and sweating, it doesn't move anymore. The screen on the iPhone 5 is already horrible in sunlight and with the shiny plastic cover on this, it is nearly impossible to see the screen at all, so things like checking distance if you have a running app or changing songs is extremely difficult. I also kind of wish the material that holds the phone in was a bit more stretchy so it could accommodate at least a very thin case. I have to take my phone completely out of its very thin case to use this arm band and that is going to get old quick. But, overall, the case does what it is intended to do. I would love to see a less reflective plastic cover more than anything and I think that would be an easy change for Belkin.

    Rating: 4

    2013-06-01: This my very first iPhone armband. I have owned many Belking electronics accessories and have always found them to be well built and nicely functional - usually at very competitive prices. When I has the opportunity to try this armband through the Amazon Vine program, I jumped on it as I have been walking more and had been thinking about getting such an armband. It looks every bit as good as it does in the pictures! Black and silver and quite handsome. The iPhone5 fits easily and snugly into the interior pocket and the earplug hole aligns well with the jack in the bottom of the iPhone. The material is light and flexible and I couldn't wait to go for my first listen-along walk with my iPhone strapped to my upper arm.The issue I encountered as soon as I began to put it on my arm has to do with sizing. The adjustment mechanism is tricky and requires a good deal of manipulation. This was necessary because it was just too large. It would begin to slide down my are almost right away, so I wanted to make it tighter. With it is small as I was able to get the strap to adjust down to, it was still too big to be secure while on a ling walk, a brief run or if sweating. For context, I am what I regard as a "Medium" size man. My biceps are just under 12". I would suppose that on a bigger person, this would work well, but I notice there is a review posted here from a man with 16" biceps who says that it is too small!It is possible that the problem is not so much with the product itself as it is with the advertising. The range of bicep sizes it is effective with probably should be overtly posted. "Best suited for people with biceps from 12" - 15" " might be an honest and USEFUL number to include in the product description. Perhaps it would be best sold in sizes S,M and L. Suggesting thast one-size-fits-all is both silly and inaccurate. It does not. 5 Stars for a nicely made product minus 3 Stars for incomplete product description = 2 Stars.

    Rating: 2

    2013-05-14: Looking at this case in the promo shots, and also when you first put it on, makes it look really nice. Streamlined, sporty, stylish. Unfortunately the function of the case is pretty bad.My issues:- There is this really cool patented Belkin 'hinge' that you adjust the band around, and then undo the hinge and it allows you to put the armband on/off, next time you put it on it will be the same tightness. Which is great, except I found it really easily to get my skin caught in it on my arm. Left me with at least one bruise. Great concept, but could use a bit more work.- Phone sits 'below' the armband. This means it looks good from the top, but the phone is pushing into your arm, including the headphone jack (this is annoying). You can also feel the phone itself pressing into your arm. Also because there is a whole for the headphone jack, sweat can also get in there.Other designs that put the iPhone above the band, solve most of these issues, but don't look as good. I wanted to love this case, but after about 2-3 miles with it, I ended up taking it off and putting my phone in the pocket instead. Switched back to my (cheaper) TuneBelt instead (and this isn't a great case, but beyond this one).

    2013-06-20: Like other reviewers, I found this armband to be very small. I was able to get it on my arm, but barely, and when I velcroed it on, it was absurdly tight. I know some of you may be wondering about my body build. Well, I am not obese by any means. I do lift weights, but I am also a woman, so am not bulky. I think most people who wear an armband will probably be working out and not necessarily have tiny arms as this band seems meant for, and therefore, it should be made for a wider variety of people.It was also difficult to get my iPhone in and out of the armband.Would I advise you buy this? No, not unless you plan to keep your phone in the armband all the time, and you have peculiarly small arms.

    2013-06-19: After reading the reviews here I was almost afraid to try this, I'm an average sized woman... who would like to loose about 25-30lbs (ie my arms are not thin, but they also aren't huge either) as it seemed that most women complained this was way too big and men said it was too small. I was also worried about the fit, I'm happy to say that my iphone 5 fits in perfectly easy and is comfortably snug. I did have to remove my case which I was hoping I might not as it's a very slim case (the LuvvittLUVVITT CRISTAL Hard Shell Anti-Scratch Transparent Case for iPhone 5 (LIFETIME WARRANTY | Retail Packaging) - Crystal Clearwhich I highly recommend) as it just wouldn't slide in with it on, though that might have been due to the slight texture on the case more then the actual size. If I'm heading out to exercise though I'm already putting on specific clothing, shoes, etc... so 10 seconds to pop off my phone case isn't a huge deal. The touch screen isn't super easy to work through the plastic, but it's not terrible easy... just have to press a bit harder then usual, but again.. I'm not checking my emails or browsing facebook, I'm starting up a playlist and that's that. I had to tighten the band a bit out of the package, and then again about midway through a jog but I still have some room to tighten it further, I agree the band is a bit intimidating at first with no direction as to how to use it but again, it's not really hard either once you mess around with it for a few mins. All in all this serves it's purpose of keeping my iphone safe and close w/o resorting to a pocket it might fall out of and isn't uncomfortably or ugly to wear. I do feel these are a bit over priced but that doesn't change the actual product rating at all. No complaints!

    2013-06-08: PROS- It holds the phone snugly to your arm--the buckle is tight enough.- The plastic front had no problems opening apps and using the phone. (But I haven't tried it with a screen protector on my phone.)CONS- It holds the phone snugly to your arm--if you're lifting with your arms you have to keep adjusting it.- The earphone hole is on the back and close to your skin, so when you're running and working out, it creates heat and condensation. So after every workout my phone was wet.- The inside of the case is so snug that you cannot have a case on your phone.Knowing all this, I would not likely buy it.

    2013-05-14: I use this armband with my iPhone 4s and my iPod nano (not both at the same time! and with a bluetooth dongle attached to the nano) for rollerskating along with some bluetooth headphones (I use the LG Tone - HBS-700). I was using my nano and dongle on a wristband, but then I started using wrist guards and could no longer wear a wristband, so I started using my iPhone 4s by putting it in the pocket of a shirt, but it's not that safe there and limits what I can wear and pulls awkwardly on that side of the shirt. So I tried this armband and it works great for my purposes (rollerskating).I wouldn't use this for any other active things I do...with the bluetooth headset my iPhone is safer in my panniers or else mounted to my handlebars when I'm riding my bike. For erging (stationary rowing) the arm movement is too extreme to hold this securely in place (and I'm better off just putting iPhone or nano off to the side somewhere.) Running I also think is too much movement and jostling. Also, of course this is not designed for the 4s, it's for the 5 iPhone (and certainly not for the nano) so it doesn't fit quite the same as it would with the proper device inside. It still works, though, and I can use the screen through the plastic, but with some difficulty. Not a good idea while riding a bike. Walking - it's not suited for a situation where you might be wearing a jacket or sweater and then later want to take it off. It might be a bit awkward over a jacket anyway.The strap fit me fine. I would say my upper arm is on the large size of medium/average for a woman. I'm basing this based on the size of elbow pads I was recently fitted for.This might not work for everyone or for every purpose, but it's just what I needed for drowning out the dreadful sound system at the roller rink!

    2013-06-24: This case didn't fit me or my wife. Then use a ruler to measure how long the string was around your bicep. If the string is 12 inches long, or longer, then this item may fit you with out slowly sliding down.Or you can wear a heavy sweater while you run so this item fits your arm.     2013-04-30: This strap from Belkin works well during my regular jogging or treadmill sessions. Once I get sweaty, it becomes a little slippery and it tends to slide when I swing a lot.     Rating: 3

    2013-06-05: This armband DOES slide down your arm during use, and the 'lacing' aspect is a little tricky. The phone-envelope is too tight to slide the phone in without taking it out of any case you might have, and the envelope doesn't seal: the top flap just slides over top of the phone.All that being said, it's comfortable on the arm even when laced snugly. It WILL slide down, but it won't unlace itself from your arm and fall straight to the ground or anything (I'm not really sure what really could be done to stop the slide, other than short up the headphone cord!) The buttons (except the mute button) can be operated through the fabric, and there's a hole in the bottom of the envelope for the headphone jack.So it's a lot better than nothing, and I'm going to continue using it! However if Belkin is listening, I'd like the envelope to be large enough to slide my cased iPhone into. I'd like the sleeve to be sealable and waterproof, with a dot on the bottom I could cut out if I REALLY want to plug in the jack.

    Rating: 4

    2013-05-06: I am having trouble finding any redeeming qualities about this product. The first terrible flaw is that the phone will get wet while you run. The back panel in the compartment where the phone fits is not water proof, so your sweat will get to the phone. In my mind, this is a crucial element an armband should have, keep your phone dry so it does not get damaged. Total fail on this one.But it does not stop there, the plastic buckle they use for adjusting the armband is awkward and rubs against your skin by running. It was not bad enough to hurt my arm, but it is far from comfortable. I Velcro strap would make a lot more sense. I saw reviews here about the armband being too small and others about it sliding down. In my case, I had to set it up to the smallest setting and it barely works. I am a male triathlete, so I have relatively thin arms, but I am pretty sure that anyone that has a runner's physique will find this armband to be too big.Finally, the product looks pretty ugly. The 5 fits like a glove. I've got a fat, chubby upper arm, although it's getting smaller due to weight loss surgery. I have been putting off getting on the treadmill as holding the phone has been a pain - but it works great on my arm without slipping. My only criticism is the buckle is tricky to use... but once you have it adjusted, you don't have to do more adjusting later unless you're losing weight.     Rating: 2

    2013-07-17: I've never used an armband before, so I can't render a judgement on how this item compares to others like it. I used this armband while walking my dog to see how it performed in that situation.My first impression was that the armband was quite large and bulky, but after thinking about it, I don't see any way that they could reduce its size, so it's probably the size that it needs to be. Sliding an iPhone 5 into place is quite snug, and I found it easier to remove the case I was using than to wrestle with the plastic sleeve.It took some time to adjust the clip just right, but after it is adjusted, the clip makes it easy to use and remove the armband. I did find that it tended to slip, even when walking, so I can understand the issues reported by others while running. I think this has to be a matter of finding a balance between having it loose enough so it doesn't feel like a blood pressure band while still holding its place.Using the phone's touchscreen was pretty easy, even if the home button was partially obscured by the top portion of the band surround. This might just be a matter of shoving the phone further into the sleeve, but given the tightness of that sleeve, I think people will run into that issue more often than not.Comfort was OK for what it was. I don't think you can get away from feeling at least a little like you have a blood pressure band on, but that may go away with time.One aspect that I thought could be improved was in the flap that covered the phone after it is inserted. The flap completely covers the phone, which is probably good from a rain protection standpoint, it makes the flap stand up completely if you are using earbuds without a right-angle connector (such as the ones included with the iPhone 5). I would like to see either a hole for the headphone jack, or that part of the flap removed so the entire flap doesn't have to make room for an earbud connector.From reading the other reviews, it seems that there are some other armbands that people like, and they are a little cheaper than this one. While I don't dislike this armband, I don't see anything spectacular about it either. For my walking purposes, I'll probably go back to putting the phone in my pocket instead of wearing this armband, especially in the hot summer weather.

    Rating: 3

    2013-07-18: I like this armband. It is adjustable enough to move from forearm use (when bicycling) to the upper arm for walking. I prefer the feature of the clip that snaps over to snug the armband vs hook-and-loop type fasteners. You are still able to adjust the "belt" slightly after it is clipped in the closed position, for fine tuning. The flap that folds over the opening on the back, where you insert the phone, helps to secure the phone in position. For the headphone jack, since I have a right-angled connector, I preferred to feed it into the case and connect to the phone vs trying to connect to the phone through the opening. I did not have any trouble operating the phone through the clear plastic cover the screen. The material is thin with a little give for comfort. I did not find it to hold a lot of sweat like the thicker lycra options I have used. I was also able to use it with an original iPod (feeding the cord inside).

    Rating: 4

    2013-05-12: I received the Belkin F8W107ttC04 Pro-Fit Armband from Amazon Vine, and I was looking forward to trying this out during my elliptial time at the gym. I normally don't bother with my iPhone and headphones during a workout, but it's something I've been wanting to try. Based on the results of this experiment, I'll go back to reading. This just didn't work on a number of levels.In order to get my iPhone in, I had to remove the case I use (which isn't that thick). Even with just the iPhone, the fit is very snug and is a bit of a hassle to get in and out (which you'll be doing plenty of). One I got it situated in the case, I tried putting it on my arm. It took a number of tries to adjust the band to get the right fit... somewhere between "don't move the arm or it will fall off" and "is this a blood pressure cuff?" The locking device doesn't seem to work very well, and it tended to dig into the skin. Even with the strap on fairly tight, it slipped down my arm repeatedly after just a little movement. At that point, it became worse than useless, as now I had to hold on to it during my workout. Add to that the fact that my sweat worked through the case, leaving the iPhone somewhat damp when I pulled it out. I'm sure that's not good for the long-term care of my iPhone...I still envy those people who seem to run effortlessly with their tunes on their arms. I may get there one day, but it won't be with this arm strap.Disclosure:Obtained From: Amazon Vine Review ProgramPayment: Free

    Rating: 2

  • B007G51X6C

    $B007G51X6C

    2013-12-03: I ended up in the hospital recently, and of course needed my Ipad to pass the time, because day time TV is so "wonderful." I did not have my AC charger or a laptop to charge from. I have an Ipad 2, which already gets great battery time, and I was able to restore my Ipad's battery to 100% from about 60-70% daily for three consecutive days without an AC charge. Without the Powerplant, my battery would have depleted to zero on my second day.I've noticed the reviews here swing wildly on the utility and reliability of this product. All I can say is it worked well for me. With so many devices that can use this product, each with its own power demands and battery sizes, it is difficult to establish a reliable benchmark for comparison. I intend to use the Powerplant to "top off" my Ipad if it is low from heavy use during the day or from an inability to recharge the night before. It has its limitations because it is difficult to replicate an AC outlet. But, in the end, it is power in your pocket, and a great alternative to a dead device. You can always try it, and if it doesn't meet your needs, return it to Amazon.Just a suggestion, but if you will lack the ability charge your device from an outlet or a computer, try and plan ahead: turn off GPS, turn off roaming for wireless networks, and reduce your screen's brightness. These are all battery hogs, and the more stretching of your battery's current charge, the less juice you'll need to charge it back up and the longer the Powerplant will last.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-18: This is a little on the pricy side -- I got to review through the Vine program -- but it was a real lifesaver for me recently on a couple of occasions. One was when I was staying in a family member's spare room with just one outlet, and the other was during a recent power outage. It charged my iPhone 5 and my Kindle Paperwhite very quickly, all the way to full -- just as fast as plugging them into a wall charger.The unit comes with a tiny micro USB cable and a USB port for you to plug in any other sort of device (like an iPhone). However, it does NOT come with its own charger (though it does include a cable). You need to use one of your other device's chargers -- I usually use the one that came with my Paperwhite.One downside: It is fairly large and heavy. I'd like to keep it in my purse for charging emergencies, but find it a little too large and bricklike.

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-31: This battery took about 24 hours to fully charge upon arrival, but then it charged up 3 cell phones fully before it needed to be recharged.     2013-11-27: Seems to work okay - charges my cellphone (Galaxy S4) just fine - seems to last 2-3 charges which is good given that that's about right for the advertised life in this. Rate of charge is good - I can use my phone and still have the battery life increasing.Handy size, easy to pack.     2013-12-16: I can't attest to the readability issues that other's have had but I can say that I've had chargers that has similar issues (gets in a state where it won't charge unless you 'reset' the device by plugging it in to a powersource).It's pretty hard to do a comprehensive review of a device which has 1 function but here are a few things I noticed from using this a few days:-it's heavier than you'd think-there are cheaper options, and more expensive as well, my favorite charger is the Duracell but costs even more than this-output is limited, you can't charge two tablets simultaneously-to the above, I couldn't charge my retina iPad to full from dead, it got to around 80% which seems low for the amps this claimsThe built in cable is super convenient and I really like that this does not require you to lug around a cable but I'm not sure if it's worth the premium for it unless you use it often and have a array of micro USB (probably Android phone(s)) devices which run out of battery. But then again a spare battery is $8 and most won't have multiple devices. My duracell has a cable but it's only 3 inches long and it can be reversed to charge it when needed.So the price point places it in the middle of the premium Duracells or the standard/cheapie chargers. Given the reliability issues other's pointed out, I probably would go up or down in the product spectrum.

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-27: At the current price (over $50) this is a tough sell, as there is a lot of competition in the market right now for similar battery packs. This pack does feature a full 2.1 amp capacity, a built-in micro-USB cable, and a sleek design. However you are paying about $5.00 per watt which is high compared to other similar devices. That said, the unit seems well made and does a nice job. It does not come with an A/C adapter for charging, you have to charge from your computer or supply your own A/C adapter. It does include a separate micro-USB cable which can be used for charging the device itself and your phones, tablets, or other devices. Together with the built-in micro-USB cable, this means you can charge two devices at one time.The included instructions are very brief and do not even mention charging the device itself except for a diagram that sort of shows the device connected to an A/C adapter (not included) port for charging (but this would be unclear to someone not familiar with these devices, I think).Here's what the manufacturer says about their not including an A/C adapter:Q: Was the PowerPlant suppose to come with a wall charger?A: The PowerPlant does not include a wall charger since it was designed with a universal micro-USB port. It does include a micro-USB cable which you can plug into any USB port to charge your PowerPlant. TYLT is committed to sustainability and providing excellent user experiences. This eliminates the need to manufacture thousands of wall chargers, reducing our ecological footprint.The unit has some built-in intelligence and you can leave it plugged in and it will not over-charge the internal battery, you can also "top off" the battery without any harm (no memory effect). TYLT says it will hold a charge for one year and that the internal battery is rated fro 500 full cycles (about standard for these devices).Here's another bit of useful information not included in the user guide (the Q&A; FAQ is at the TYLT web site):Q: How do I know that the Powerplant is fully charged?A: While charging the Powerplant all 4 LEDs will turn off signifying that the device has a full 100% charge.I struggled with rating this device. It has a premium price, so the "value" proposition is low. But it does have a good design and features. Reliability is unknown (I note some earlier reviews indicating some quality control issues, hopefully those have been resolved by now). The device has a one year warranty. Overall, it is a good design, with attractive styling, and it has the built-in micro USB cable which is nice. I am going to be generous and give it 4 stars based on the full 2.1 amp power-rating and features. For now, that's my best judgement for the TYLT UPPLANT2-T.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-11: Firstly, the Tylt PowerPlant is a portable 'battery driven' charger in which you do not need to plug it into a wall to use its power. You will plug it into a USB charger to charge this PowerPlant when it depletes however that is only after you have used it.When I say "battery-driven" I do not mean that you need batteries to run this because it is an enclosed rechargeable device.This being said, this mini 'PowerPlant' does exactly what is described to do. Think of this as a very small and portable laptop charging station for your USB devices.[---Testing---]Ipod completely decharged (note you should not do this to your own device as for maximum life you should start charging your devices at around 20% of battery life) recharged completely in less than an hour.The PowerPlant, after charging the iPod, still had half its life left.-------------To charge the PowerPlant, you will need a USB charger input (as mentioned above). The cord with a mini-USB male connector is included with it so that you do not have to buy it separately.[---Size---]About 3" or about 7.5 cm long and about 2" wide or 5 cm. Is very light and needs no mention with regards to weight.** When using, it had (4) green LED lights on the outside which tell you how much life is left on the PowerPlant, it will also display how much life is left on the device being charged **------------------------------------As there are many times I have had devices fail because I did not expect that I would be using it heavily during certain times, or when I forgot simply to bring a charger or had no place to charge my devices from. For the traveler, or for a convenient means to quickly charge your devices from a high quality 'battery pack' the Tylt is a prudent buy in the field of prevention.

    2013-11-27: I have used this power bank for several weeks, and so far I like it, though I don't love it. It powers my Samsung Galaxy 3 and my Kindle Paperwhite. There's a little USB cord, or "flex arm" attached to it that you can use to charge your micro USB device. I like that you can't lose it. I can lose almost anything, but this will take some extra effort to lose this "arm". There's also a traditional USB cord, that I haven't lost yet either, but it won't be as hard. I haven't had the problems some other reviewers have had regarding having to recharge this battery in order to reset it to recharge something else.The only thing I don't really like is how boxy this is. Yes, it's small, but it uses up a lot more space than you would think. I like some of my thinner batteries better.

    2013-12-03: I like the form factor - this little battery is compact enough to be convenient but not so small it gets lost in my various tech bags. It is, however, chunky enough that I wouldn't want to carry it around in my pocket. It's handy but not quiet sufficiently small to be ideal for what I really need: reliable, small juice for my 2+ year old phone whose battery is lasting less than a day on average.Mine does not seem to retain a charge. I charged this when I first got it as mine arrived charged at 2 of 4 LEDs on. I forgot about it for a week and decided to plug it into a charger, despite it saying it was fully charged (4 lights on) before plugging it in, and upon plugging it in it's down to 2 LEDs and charging.I tested charging an iPad (3rd gen), iPhone 4s and Kindle Paperwhite. They all worked, they all charged up reasonably quickly. The battery lasted longer on iPhone and Kindle charges, of course - the iPad is just a hog. But it did get the iPad to 100% full (I've had problems with other batteries not being able to top off the iPad).It warms up, but I wouldn't say it gets too hot. It's actually stays cooler than my phone after an hour-long call.Pros:Nice sizeConvenient USB mini cable built inBattery itself charges with any USB mini cable - I used a usb mini to outlet set up to charge it rather than plugging it into my computerCharged relatively quickly - about 10% per hour on the iPadDecent capacity - actually had multiple phone charges per battery chargeCons:LEDs don't seem to be accuratePricyA good size, but if it were flatter/slimmer, I'd be a bigger fan.

    2013-11-09: * The power capacity is great - 5200 mAh. I powered my wife's Samsung Galaxy S III three consecutive times and still had a little charge left. I don't have another battery that can do that. That's why I like this so much.* Light indicators are reliable when the battery is charging something. 4 green dots can go to 2 and than back up to 4. That kind of thing happens, so I don't believe those lights when it's charging my iPad or phone.* It's maybe heavier than its size would hint at but still better than carrying two separate batteries.     2013-12-15: Unit has a 2 amp capability, which means it will charge a device similar to a regular manufacturer plug for those larger devices such as smartphones. I found this made a huge difference compared to the Duracell versions of powerpacks. Rating is 5200 MaH. I got a full charge on my Note 3 with power to spare of about half a charge on the rest.     2013-12-18: This a great little device. It is pretty small and packs a lot of juice. I mainly keep it in my computer bag but rarely use it. It gets a lot of use when we go camping.     2013-10-27: This is a really handy charging device. It's small and light and yet has enough energy to charge a phone many times. There's a button on one end that lights a series of LEDs to tell you how much charge is left. The other end has a rubber flap that covers an input and an output connector. There's also an integral flexible output connector/cable on one side. It comes with a USB to microUSB cable. The one thing that's missing is the AC charging unit. The one that came with my smart phone works fine (5v, 1a), but it would be nice to have one that could be carried with this unit. It also seems a bit pricey.

    2013-12-19: The UPPLANT is really built for the glove box from the rated 12 hour power supply to the ability to hold a charge for up to a year. When I first saw the UPPLANT that was actually my thought, 'how long does it hold the charge?', My thinking was if I had to pull it out of the glove box every month or two to recharge because of drain it wouldn't be practical for me but one of the first things I saw on the box was that it holds a charge for up to a year. Perfect!It has a button to let you know the level of charge. Includes a USB to Micro USB cable. Built in micro USB cable. Has a USB and Micro USB output ports and a Micro USB input port.A couple of minor negatives, wish it had included fold-away AC prongs similar to the Tylt ENERGI2 and the rubber flap covering the ports doesn't close properly. An essential glove box accessory, very highly recommended.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-01: This device is not much bigger than a d-cell battery, but it packs a powerful charge for on-the-go charging of your high-draw devices that you can let go dead. This system charged up my blackberry bold from 1/4 to full in about an hour. I usually keep the phone on charge for about an hour after lunch and that day I forgot and this device saved me some trouble.It has a port you charge it with, a standard USB port, and a very helpful micro-USB cable that is built into the case and plugs right into your device and start pumping electricity into it right away!it also has a very helpful charge level gauge so you can see how much capacity it has left in it. As I recall, it took a couple of hours to charge to full capacity, but I wasn't watching it all the time, so it could have been faster than that.It also has built-in covers so that it can help to keep the dust out of it and the contacts clean.I have tested several of these devices and I think this is the most powerful I have seen for its size.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-12: This extended battery offers good capacity (it can give most smartphones between two to four full charges and supplies good charge current.One end is fitted with a rubber cover which protects the charging port (microUSB) and a USB port. On the opposite end, the power/battery level button and the four LED power indicator. On the side, a short microUSB rubber cable connects to most devices.the UPPLANT2-T comes with a USB to microUSB cable, but no power adapter.In terms of functionality and features, it's very similar to theMotorola dual charging power pack-- with about four times the capacity.I LIKED- the built-in connector, one less cable to forget- the standard microUSB connector for charging- the additional USB socket for charging a second device- the capacity as well as the amperage available: it can charge my Nexus 7, a notoriously finicky device- the excellent build qualityI DISLIKED- the omission of a high power fast charger. A device with high power requirement like a tablet will drain the battery faster than you can charge it.- the price: at the time of this review, it's very high for this capacity- the shape: despite its comfortable rounded corners, it's too thick to comfortably fit in a pocketTHE BOTTOM LINEThe UPPLANT2-T is a good external battery, with a convenient built-in charging cord and a nice design. A wider, flat design would have made it a great pocket battery, but as it is you will have to relegate it to your gadget bag (but it's sure nice to have on a long plane trip!)

    2013-11-21: This is a great little charger that can fit in your pocket (it doesn't get too hot when charging your device).
