    2013-10-29: The Tylt powerplant is essentially a rechargeable battery with multiple usb ports (both full size and micro). It is a brilliant solution for those who travel with mobile devices (and often too many cords and chargers). This unit can be used with effectively anything that charges via usb.The manufacturer claims that t will hold its charge for a year and charge a phone for up to 12 hours. I have not had it long enough (or batteries worn down enough) yet to check that claim, but it will recharge your phone or tablet in a pinch. It also works with other devices, but I know from experience it does not last as long with netbooks.The batttery has a micro usb andc universal female usb ports and can charge 2 devices at once. It also comes with a 1 year manufactuer's warranty.The Unit has an led which shows the charge level and comes with a usb charging cable. This is the only thing which took it down a notch for me. It takes a lot longer to recharge via usb than ac or dc, and if you are on the road with devices running out of juice, do you want to plug it into one to charge another? They do refer to it as a home charging cable, but that is somet5hing to bear in mind, and is not an issue with the similarSanyo eneloop KBC-L2B Mobile Boosterwhich comes with a plug in charger as well. he Sanyo is also a bit lighter, but may not hold a charge as long. Thus far I am fiding them both useful and only in extreme circumstances would one likely need more. It is now part of my mobile tool kit so that I no longer have to worry when i find my phone dead at the end of a long trip, as invariably do.

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-27: This portable USB battery pack works fairly well but the voltage drops quite a bit when you're charging a device with it. What this means is the 4 green LEDs will not give you an accurate indication of remaining capacity. For example many times while charging a device that's plugged into this battery pack, only one LED will be lit which would suggest around 20% or less capacity remaining. This however is not accurate because if you unplug the device and let the battery sit for awhile the one LED will change to 2, 3 or even 4 when the voltage is allowed to recover.With that said there's a built-in flexible rubber flip out micro USB cable in addition to a standard USB port behind a protective rubber flap. Both can be used at the same time regardless whether or not the battery pack itself is being charged. Build quality is ok and the battery pack is not too large but the shape is not ideal for pocketing.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-04: I have this charger for a couple of weeks now and finally got a chance to use it. I had the UPPLANT2 on full charge and took it with me on a long trip. I plug my iPad in when the iPad was down to 65% battery, and continue to play video for another 2 hours. At the end of 2 hours my iPad got to 95% charge, but the UPPLANT2 was down to nothing! May be there is still some juice in there as the iPad still show the lightning bolt (charging), but no LED lights left. I believed if I only charge the iPad and not playing video, performance will much be better. If you plan to use this charger with your smartphone, I think you will get more out of it. I have a Kensington battery pack model K38201 that could charge a single iPhone, but is much thinner and more portable. The Kensington could probably bring my iPad to about 30% charge from empty, so the UPPLANT2 definitely packs more power!The device is compact, only about 3 1/2' x 1 1/2" x 1", so it is easy to toss into the briefcase. Add a couple of charging cables for your devices and you are all set. On the road, you can charge it with your computer or a USB charger, just remember this device takes microUSB as input. I also used this device with my personal hotspot, and it worked great! For devices that are not that power hungry, the UPPLANT2 definitely fits the bill.

    Rating: 4

    2013-12-25: This device suites me exactly. On day long business trips my iPhone typically runs low by early afternoon and this small, lightweight device provides a handy boost without needing to resort to looking for wall plugs. The only negative thing is that this device needs to be recharged through a USB connection instead of a wall connection, making it slightly more inconvenient.

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-31: While the Powerplant is a great idea and can be used for multiple types of electronics, it definitely has its drawbacks. For one, the four LED light indicator is unreliable. It will show four light, drop to two in a matter of minutes. Attempting to charge is a bit challenging at times because I am unsure if it is working. I'll plug in my iPhone, turn on the Powerplant and the lights will go blank, while other times they will stay on for a bit. As well, why not ship with an ACTUAL wall charger? It's not always convenient to charge from your laptop with the provided cable. I'm not a fan of electronics that rely on this type of charging cable. I think the company should rethink the design to create a series of Powerplants which focus on certain electronics, such as a Powerplant specifically for iPhones/iPads with two male ends right on the Powerplant for both old and new iPhone adapters. As well, make the unit smaller, and add a wall charger. Needless to say, I won't be using this unit much because it seems unreliable, but if there is ever an updated version, I may use it.

    Rating: 3

    2013-11-20: This is the third one I've owned (first of this brand). Of the three, this one has the smallest battery capacity, but there are a few things that I do like over the other two:1) This one is smaller than the others. Portability, especially when working with portable electronics, is always a plus!2) The price is pretty good for $35. A good price for when you need a quick pickmeup on your battery.3) Charges at 2.1 watts, which can fully charge my phone in about an hour. I've got some wall chargers that have charged it slower.4) The little green cable inside negates the need to carry around an extra cable. Just pull it out and use it right away.That said, there are some negatives to keep in mind:1) Having this basically gives my phone one full charge. After that, this guy is drained. So, while it is smaller than most others, I get the least amount of mileage from it than the others. I price kind of reflects that.2) The little green cable is on a very short leash, so carrying this and a phone is awkward, to say the least. There is a USB out option as well if you have a longer cable that negates this problem. Still, I'd rather have a short green cable than no cable at all.3) I wish it would sit flatter. Right now, it is nearly cube shaped. so it doesn't fit in my pocket or store conveniently at all.I'm still leaving the rating at 5-stars. Yes, this isn't perfect, but I don't expect much else for the price. You can get better, but you'll need to spend more for it.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-30: I like spare battery systems like this especially when traveling, but even just a spare in car can be a lifesaver. Overall it's not a bad deal based on the specs, it has enough power to more than fully charge a modern smart phone, it can charge two things at once, and you don't need to bring a micro USB cable. My complaints are that it's a clunky shape, it would be more ergonomic if it was half and tall and twice as wide/long for a more phone shaped end product... Also the rubber flap that protects the USB ports feels more annoying than whatever protection it offers me... I'd also really like one of these battery packs come with a built in self-charging plug or at least a slide out USB plug so you don't need to bring any cables. Finally, while it may not be the most well rounded battery pack and not tight pocket friendly, it's certainly capable of giving you more power then pretty much any other pack in it's price range and that alone makes it worth considering.PROS:+ Lots of capacity+ Two devices at once+ Pass through charging+ Built in micro USB cableCONS:- Odd shape- Annoying cover- No built in charging cable/plug for the battery itself

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-31: This Lithium-Ion power charger works great, when I first opened this it was 70% charged (best for storage) so charged it up before using. By the way the charger isn't included but most cell phone mini USB chargers work fine, they just take a long time. I use this charger as a back-up power supply when I'm away from other power sources, like hiking or at the ball game. I find this power charger is very robust as it has plenty of reserve, 5200 mAh capacity. It charged my cell phone in about 50 minutes and still showed 3 lights out of 4 in the power display. I have charged my cell 3 times before recharging the Tylt powerplant so am pleased with the capacity.It gets slightly warm when using so don't be concerned, it shouldn't get hot. You can use the micro-usb flex arm that tucks away in the side or the main USB plug or both at the same time. Having 5200 mAh of power allows you to charge most tablets too!

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-17: Good capacity. Small but boxy shape. The built in cable is nice if you primarily need a micro USB to charge devices. I don't and have to use my own cables.I now have several of these backup batteries and this is my advice. Decide how much capacity you need. Compare the weights of the devices. The weights usually are consistently proportional to the capacity. Avoid ones that are unnecessarily heavy. Then chose the best value for the capacity you need.Most provide some way to connect to almost any portable device with the right cables and the other features don't turn out to be that important.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-08: Like many other reviews I've had mixed results with this item. When it works it does so well. It holds a good charge and I was able to charge/top off both a Galaxy S4 phone and Nexus 7 before exhausting it.The bad part is that it won't always charge items, even if the battery itself is completely charged. And if I have trouble the only way I found to fix it is plug it back in to charge the battery itself.Also I found it won't charge from most other USB chargers, like computers, hubs, 12v chargers and the like. The only way I've been 100% successful is to charge it using a converted plugged into a wall socket.This item would easily be a 5 star rating if/when they sort out its reliability issues.

    Rating: 3

    2013-11-01: I like the style and look of this external battery. It recharges fast, and gives my cell phone a quick boost if the battery runs low. I've also used to to power several other usb devices, and it works quite well. The capacity is a tad small, but decent. However, I see why other reviewers have complained that theirs broke -- the rubber flap on the end of the battery covers the charging ports isn't hinged very well. So I really gotta peel back that flap to get it out of the way of those ports. This repeated motion of prying back to open, and then squishing it all back to close, will most definitely result in a short lifespan for that rubbery flap. Same is true for the additional micro-usb arm -- that rubbery design just won't last and will stretch out over time. Personally, I don't care if the flap itself breaks. Sure, it protects the ports, but it adds nothing to the function of this battery. The rubbery arm, however, is another story; if it breaks, it takes out a charging port with it. The blocky design of the battery itself makes this a little bulky in the pocket. But I do like the hidden green accents that appear when the flaps are opened. It looks classy, but doesn't seem durable. Time will tell. Decent overall.

    2013-11-21: There are a few things that I look for in an external USB battery. This is how this one compares :+ Capacity : at 5200 mAh, it should be able to recharge most smartphones twice. Decent.+ Size : Fairly compact, especially for the capacity. Not quite pocketable, unless you wear cargo pants (and only if you want to be at the receiving end of "or are you happy to see me" / "does this make my butt looks big" jokes.+ Built in cable : Has a micro USB cable. This is convenient because it means you don't need to pack another cable, unless you need to charge the battery pack.+ USB port : Allows you to use your own cable for anything that doesn't take micro USB.+ Allows charging while being charged : This allows me to connect my cell phone to the battery, and battery to my charger, at night before I go to bed. By next morning, everything is fully charged. The pack will only start charging the phone when it is close to fully charged, if it is being charged itself.However, the unit itself has some flaws that prevent me from giving it a higher rating :- The cable and rubber flap that protects the ports is hard to replace properly. The cable is also rather short.- The built-in cable will not recharge my Nexus 7 (2013 version). Using a micro USB cable with the battery's USB pack works fine.- The battery indicator LED is horribly inaccurate. Once, after fully charging my phone, it still shows 4 lights (full capacity). After another 5 minutes of charging, it suddenly drops to 2.- Battery does not seem to stop charging on its own.

    Rating: 3

    2013-11-03: If you need to extend the battery life on your equipment this will do the job fairly quickly. It's light and elegant, with a charge cable equipped with a velcro wrap to keep things neat and tidy. When you get this unit, it comes charged. Depress the status button, and you will see those 4 green lights pictured on the unit. It promises up to 10 hours of extended charge. Use it to charge your electronics, and you will lose 2 green lights (or what appears to be half the unit's ability to charge) immediately. But it does charge. It fully charged a Kindle Fire HD from 12% to 100% in 5 hours. If you try to recharge the UPPLANT2-T, it will take 5 hours. The minute you connect anything to this unit, it appears to lose half the charge.Which means you don't always know what you've got. The charge cord doesn't give you a lot of confidence that your Tylt UPPLANT2-T is giving your 'up to 10 hours.' But it offers more charge time than anything this size, weight and configuration has any right to do.So why the 3 stars? This unit has some of the worst documentation I have ever seen anywhere. There is no clear warranty or apparent way to get redress should it be needed. Worst of all, in its elegance, this unit is so tightly constructed it was challenging to find out how to use it. The 'manual' was not much help. I had to approach it as if it were a rubik's cube in order to use it at all, or recharge it. So I give it 3 stars and call that fairly generous.

    2013-10-27: The Tylt Upplant2-T is one of the best designed portable battery packs I've seen. However, at over $50 for 5200 mAh of battery life, it's not a good bargain when compared to others.The battery life is decent - you'll get about 2.5x smartphone charges and about half of an iPad charge. You'll be able to charge two devices at the same time, which is rather nice. I charged an iPhone and a Blackberry from the battery pack at the same time and still had a little bit of juice to spare. There's no AC adapter so you'll be charging this off your computer via the included Micro-USB cable.Overall, the battery pack does what it says and matches up with the performance. However, when looking at the price, there are a vast number of battery packs with the same capacity for $20 cheaper. Even battery packs with double the capacity are less than the Tylt Upplant2-T. This pack, in its defense, it a great looking device, but I'd rather have an ugly battery pack if it was cheaper.

    Rating: 3

    2013-12-04: I've charged my iPhone a few times with the Tylt Upplant2-t without any issues. I haven’t charged 2 devices simultaneously like the description says. If it works I think it would draw a lot of power and drain the Tylt quickly. I was expecting more than 1 and half charges of my phone from the 5200 mAh capacity battery. The rubber flap that covers the ports doesn’t stay in place very well. Beside the cover and the battery capacity the Upplant2-t is a good little device. The size of the device is perfect for charging in my pocket or my wife’s purse. Other reviewers have complained about the battery life indicator lights not working. I haven’t really noticed this issue but I don’t use the indicator much. The Tylt is a little expensive. You can get a larger mAh battery pack for the price or cheaper. Overall, I think the Tylt Upplant2-t is a good portable battery pack.

    2013-11-02: Edit, I just saw the comment about longevity and I will come back later if this product fails. I've only had it a couple of weeks right now.I got this and the duracell powermat at the same time. If you were going to invest in the powermat system, it might be easier, but you get a lot less charging for your $ because of the clever powermat design.So, why only four stars? In a word, quality and workmanship ;-) First, let me say it works great. I plugged my Note 3 in with 73% charge and watched it recharge at just better than 1% per minute. So in fifteen minutes I had a fully charged phone again. About an hour and a half to charge from 0-100 in my limited testing on a Note 3. That seemed pretty good to me. I'm guessing a battery with more mah (like 10,000 or 15,000) might have a higher amp rate and charge faster, but this felt good to me.The device is relatively small, chunky and nice looking. The button, leds and connectors all make sense and work well. It closes up into a nice box once you are done.That is where the star comes off though, the rubber connector links don't fit snugly and the cover doesn't ever feel like it is on SNUGLY. This thing could easily be waterproof with a little more attention to detail here. How cool would it be if you could accidentally wash it in your pants without ruining it? I think a tiny bit of quality improvement could make this a reality.Overall, this is a really good charger at a really good price. You can probably get about 1 & 1/3 to 2 charges depending on your device. I would gladly recommend this.

    Rating: 3

    2013-10-30: I got this product for review from Amazon and I have been testing it for past few days, The Product itself is useful in emergency situations wherein you do not have A/C power source to charge your Smartphone or Tablet. It does charge an average smartphone from fully discharged state to full battery charge may be 1 and half times maximum before dying out. It can also charge bigger iPad 3/4 tablet or 10 inch Samsung tablets too from zero to about 40% charge capacity before dying out which is not too bad in emergency situations.The Tylt Powerplant came fully charged (When you press the button all the 4 LED lights up) But as soon as you start using the powerplant, the LED lights starts acting up. It drops from 4 LEDs (Full power) to about 2 LEDs in less than 5 mins. After that it shows 1 LED when you press the button. It does keep charging despite this LED display weirdness till the Powerplant's battery is really dead.Now comes the problem. Tylt powerplant does not come with its own charger, So you will have to use your own, for example using it to charge from a USB port on your PC. Well that's where I ran into issues. I used the included charging cable and attempted it to charge on a regular PC port and nothing happened. No lights, nothing. I started to investigate the issue and found that the device was attempting to draw too much current exceeding 500mA so my PC's USB port would shutdown. So I attempted it on a 1A car cigarette lighter port based USB charger and that too had issues wherein it would detect overload and shutdown.I started to believe that Tylt Powerplant was dead, But I still could not convince myself how a perfectly working electronics can go from fully working to completely 'dead short' by merely discharging completely to an attach device which it was designed for and go dead? - Hmmm... fishy & Quirky indeed. Thanks to many other 2.1A or higher USB chargers and DC-to-DC converters that are lying around in my house I started to attempt to kick start this Tylt Powerplant one by one after about 2-3 attempts it came back to life finally using Kindle Fire USB charger (Which is 2.1A) wherein the Green LED started to blink indicating that it is charging the internal battery. It took almost 6-7 hours before the Green LEDs powered off indicating a full charge.This lead me to conclude that if you ever fully discharge the Tylt Powerplant as intended the charging circuit draws too much initial current to recharge the internal battery thereby overloading a regular USB port & some low powered USB chargers. You need to connect to a 2.1A or higher USB powered charger to rejuvenate the device back to normal. This also explains why some people has commented that it stops working after few months of use.Moral of the story - Do not fully discharge your Tylt Powerplant. The other reason for my 2 star rating is the price. IMHO, There are better alternatives out there.Thanks for reading my review.

    Rating: 2

    2013-11-07: This is a good idea it's just too darn bulky for any real world applications. Carrying it around would be a hassle (business people with briefcases and the like would be the exception and perhaps students with backpacks). The micro usb connection is a good idea but weirdly done with a short rubberized arm that bends in any angle but if you're charging your phone and want to use it you're going to have a large black ear ring hanging off your phone that weighs too much to ignore!. It can charge two devices at once as long as one of them uses a micro usb port. The indicator lights are misleading and whimsically offer an unrealistic estimate of how much power is actually left in the thing at any given moment. It says power gone come back later and it'll say two lights worth left...that sort of thing. All that said it does do what it says. It charged my phone from almost dead to full in about the same time the wall charger takes. Yesterday it charged my Acer Iconia and my phone (albeit taking a much longer time) and still had a little power left. So it works..it's just bulky and there are slimmer smaller just as efficient units out there if you look. The Energizer XP8000AB comes to mind as an example. This costs less tho and does function well so if bulky doesn't bother you you're good to go. I've had none of the problems outlined in some of the other reviews. It worked right out of the box and worked well. I just don't wanna have to lug it around.

    2013-12-19: I usually like to travel with a battery back-up just in case my battery gets low when I'm out and about. There are a few positive things about this device. It does have the ability to charge two devices at once. It has a built-in micro USB charger. As far as negatives, this portable battery is much heavier and bulkier than other brands that I have. Length wise, it's about the length of my palm, but it is rather thick. It's size does not make it difficult to just throw in my pocket without looking ridiculous. It is also rather heavy compared to my other back up battery. It took a little while to charge up the first time. The built-in micro usb is convenient, but it is kind of hard to get the plug into my phone due to my case on my phone. It has a light indicator to show how much battery you have left. Charging up my smartphone used 3/4 lights worth of the battery. So I doubt that even if you were charging two devices at the same time, that you would be able to get them both fully charged (unless they are low drain devices). It does get the job done, thus the 3 stars, but it's not my favorite external battery option.

    2013-11-13: I consider this charger for longer travels. I've tested it out on a long trip to Florida and San Francisco and it works nicely for keeping my phone powered.     Rating: 4

    2013-11-04: I like this device, but... (don't you just hate seeing a review start out that way? I wish another direction would have worked better here, but in the end, that seemed the most effective way to go so off I went and here we go...)First up, I would note this device fits into a category with other similar devices, such as aTylt ENERGI2-T Energi for Micro USB Devices(which is slightly mis-named/described, as it will also charge devices that would require other types of USB connections), and another device that I had bought ages ago from {now} Amazon subsidiary, Woot. That device would be theEnergizer XP2000 Universal Rechargeable Power Pack(or similar). There's also an alternative from Duracell, theDuracell Powermat GoPower Overnighter Batterywhich I also recently reviewed (and liked, except for the packaging that seems designed to lock that device into permanently ;) )Personally, I tend to favor the Energizer gadget of the bunch as I like that it came with an assortment of accessories including assorted charging tips, a carrying bag, additional cables, and more. It was priced (at the time I ordered it) in the neighborhood of the pricing for this device, which, as I look around, was a bargain.This device (the TYLT UPPLANT2-T) promises the ability to charge two devices at the same time, but does so while confusing the user with battery status indicators that don't necessarily relate back to reality. After charging a device for a bit, the lights may go out in a fashion that would lead you to believe more of the charging capacity of this device has been consumed than really has. Leave the device sit for a while and come back and attempt to use it and the indicators may show that more battery life remains than was indicated when you stopped charging earlier. Basically the charge indicators don't reflect a 1 to 1 relationship between the capacity that remains and how much you see on these lights.Charging this device may also be a bit problematic. If you aren't working with a 2.1A charger, you would probably be well advised to switch to one. Otherwise this device may not charge well or nearly as quickly as you might desire.It is OK for what it was designed for, and compared to current pricing on the Energizer XP8000 that I love so much, it is fairly inexpensive. I'm thankful that I was able to try this device out, but don't know that I could recommend running out to buy one too quickly. I would say that if it was to include a separate charger that easily plugged into A/C power (like it's little cousin, theTylt ENERGI2-Tdoes, even if it wasn't using a flip out plug as that one does), it would probably be a better deal.One last thought here, this is a device that considerably thicker than the Energizer XP8000 and, obviously, its own cousin, theTylt ENERGI2-T Energi for Micro USB Devices. That may make it harder to find room for in your own carrying cases. That is again certainly an area where the smaller units prove to be a better solution.

    Rating: 3

    2013-11-01: The Tylt powerplant is a nice little portable charger for those on the go. It has 1 USB port and an integrated microUSB cord. It can be charged using your computer's USB port with the included cable. If you want to use your car or the wall, you will need to invest in a USB adapter for those outlets, or use one that you may already own.The Good:It's compact and essentially fool proof. If you can plug in a USB cable, you're golden.Charging is at least as fast as your wall charger.Battery capacity is larger than your average cellphone's so you can get multiple charges.LED indicators to let you know what the battery's level is at.Charge two devices simultaneously as long as one uses a microUSB.The Not-so-Good:Heavy. It's a battery so it does have some heft to it. May not be comfortable to carry around in your purse or shoulderbagYes, it charges two devices simultaniously, but one HAS to be a micro USB. May dissuade Apple users from the purchase.Attached microUSB cable is very short, it would be very uncomfortable to attempt to talk on the phone while using the device as you would have a 2 pound battery hanging off it. This may also inhibit the use of other devices while charging as well.Overall:It's a solid product. I noticed that other reviewers voiced complaints regarding the longevity of the device. I have only owned the device for a week, so I cannot speak to that factor. I have experienced no issues with the device and it works straight out of the box, exactly as it is advertised. My only real concern is that there's a limited market. I rarely find myself without a car charger (much cheaper than this device) or a USB port nearby. I think if you do a lot of camping or hiking, it'd be great to have. Most people probably won't find it's infrequent application worth the price tag.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-07: The Tylt Powerplant is a USB/microUSB charger made for recharging portable devices on the go. It has a lot of nice features, such as a compact design, built-in swing-out micro-USB charger arm that will connect with any micro-USB device, eliminating the need for a separate micro-USB cable, and a second regular sized USB port for plugging in a USB cable for other products that use a USB-connected cable (30-pin or lightening cable for iProducts, for example). A rubberized cover snaps into place to cover the connectors when they are not in use. It has an LED green light indicator on it so you can quickly check the power level. With the quick push of a small, black button, the LED lights will light up (0-4), letting you know how much charge is left in the device. Recharging the product is done through an AC/USB adapter (NOT included) and a micro-USB cable (included). The charger came 3/4 full and charged to 100% in less than 10 minutes.In terms of charging capacity, the product description claims it can charge two devices simultaneously. It has a 5200mAh capacity, 2.1A output (roughly 10W). Based on the mAh capacity, it should be able to charge a iPhone 3-4 times. With my iPhone at 40%, it was able to charge it to 100% in less than an hour (maybe a lot less-I didn't check), but only dropped one power level (from 4 to 3 lights). However, when my son used it to charge up his iPhone that was completely dead, it used 3/4 of the total charge. He did leave it plugged in all day, so it might have continuously drained it throughout the day. Charging a Samsung Galaxy, it drained the battery by about 50%, and was able to charge my iPod Touch completely with the remaining charge and still wasn't completely drained. **I think it is safe to say you will be able to get two full Smartphone charges out of one full battery.**I am not sure the LED power level display works. At one point after a brief charge, the LED indicator read 3 lights (75% full). However, after sitting for a few minutes, it mysteriously read 4 lights (fully charged), without being recharged.One design flaw is the rubberized port cover. After a few weeks of pretty consistent use, I have been having trouble getting the cover to stay closed. I keep the battery in my work bag in case I need it on the go (it is light-weight and compact enough to carry around with me), but I have noticed that the ports are starting to get dusty inside. Even if I am able to get the cover sort-of closed, the edges still pop open, meaning the ports will eventually get dirty. I don't know if it is that big of a deal, but it is just a note. The micro-USB arm also isn't staying as secure in its little area either, so I do worry that it may get stretched out if it gets jammed between two items in my bag. I will need to keep it in a side pocket or something to keep it safe. Maybe if it came with a carrying case of some sort, it would be better than the rubberized cover?Another minor point is that it didn't come with an AC adapter. I have tons, but another adapter is a little extra that is always good to have around.Thus, I give the Tylt Powerplant 4 stars. It appears to charge as well as other battery chargers I have used, but the minor design flaws and possible LED power level indicator issues take it from 5 to 4 stars.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-04: The integrated plug is a little strange, almost like a rubber arm, but I was able to plug it into my phone without removing the phone case. If it did not fit, I do have the option of using the standard output, which some chargers in this price range lack. It does not have a wall charger, I do not get this, since charging from a high powered wall charger speeds up the charging time.I was able to charge my Nexus 4 from 10% to 95% and then again from 15% to 75% while the phone had WIFI off and was in Airplane mode. You can charge two things at once, (I did this with a Sansa Clip and the Nexus 4) but it slowed down the charging speed.I like the rubber cover, as it means junk is less likely to get into it when I throw it in my electronics bag. I uploaded a photo of it next to a soda can for size.The green lights that show you how much charge you have left go off a second after you turn the device on. This is annoying as you cannot see how much power is left. However, since the lights are not actually a great representation of how much charge is left, this may be just an annoyance.With a high power wall charger (2.1A) it took 6 hours to charge from one green light back up to four. I did not take it down to zero (and that means you have to keep an eye on it and keep checking it by pushing the button) since a lot of lithium ion batteries have trouble if you drop them down to zero.The sticker will not peel off nicely. I hate that.I really like the idea of a backup charger, but the reality is that with a car charger the times I will use this the most is during air travel. It is too large and heavy to carry around all the time in my purse. I have tried to buy in the past, AA or AAA based backup chargers, but those never worked for devices that draw a lot of current, so I gave up on them.

    Rating: 3

    2013-12-19: This charger holds a lot of charge, but it is also one of the bulkier spare chargers that I have. It's a bit clunky and brick-like so it's not one of my more favorite to lug around. The shape just does not fit that well in my purse. But when I want the most power, this is the one that I reach for. It has a LED power indicators, which is good. Then on one end, it has a rubber door that flips open. It has an attached micro-usb cable that is very short and therefore, not very versatile. Then it has a USB port so you can charge anything else you want. Personally, I would have just preferred 2 USB ports, that would provide the most versatility. It seems to hold it's charge well when not in use and charges well.

    Rating: 4

    2013-12-02: This is similar to the various other portable/mobile charging units I have. The unit is fairly bulky compared to others, but it is rechargeable and can charge more than 1 item. My main issue is that it does not charge quickly, is fairly touchy to get it charged correctly, and it doesnt stay charged long.I expect my backup "emergency charger" to actually stay charged for a long period of time; I do NOT want another item I have to keep charged up all the time.I have several mobile devices and occasionally need to charge them before they day is up, so I keep a backup battery charger. This one has a battery life that requires you to keep a charger handy, so whats the point? I have gone back to my old standy which is powered by AAA batteries, so I dont need to worry about keeping it constantly charged.

    Rating: 3

    2013-10-26: My iPad was down to about 18% charge two hours ago. I plugged in this backup and have been working steadily for the past few hours and am up to 44% charge on the iPad. The TYLT did not come with a cable, I used the original one form the iPad. There is a built in plug to charge an iPhone at the same time. Very handy for the multitaskers in the family. I like the design of the built in plug, very sleek, compact and useful. The LED light button did light up right out of the box after holding it down for a few seconds I saw one bar. Now after 2 hours of charge time there are no more bars and my iPad charge seemed to stop at 43%. I'll have to go plug it into my PC, something I would prefer not to do. It would be so much easier to recharge in a wall socket , as I do not travel with the desktop PC.

    Rating: 4

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-09: Installation for these really is a pain. There really is no easy way to perfectly align the back on a Nexus 5 other than just taking the extra time and lining it up. I cut out the camera with a razor and lined everything up that way. Then taped the top half securely in place. Lifted the bottom half and starting at the center laid the bottom half down. This would be much more easily accomplished if there was a split in the backing from Cruzerlite.The reason I didn't give this a 5 has nothing to do with the installation. I only wanted to put a back on my Nexus. I wasn't sure the color so I ordered a few. I took my time and insured everything was lined up perfectly. In each case, there was a tiny amount which went over the edge and I trimmed off with a razor. If I was installing the entire skin, this may not have been an issue, I wasn't installing the entire skin so it was an issue.

    2010-11-23: First off, I've been using iPhone 3G for about 3 years and still love it despite the short battery life and surprisingsly still works just fine after everyday usage. Since I've heard so much good things about Google operating system I wanted to buy another phone and try it out. I first bought Motorola XT720 with Android 2.1 but realized that the SD memory with over 7gb couldn't be used when downloading apps from Google market!? So I ran out of memory after using up only few thousand megabytes of the phone memory. There were other flaws such as not being able to create Yahoo email accounts for quick viewing of all the email accounts with out loging in and loging out with each email. Whereas iPhone you can have Gmails and Yahoo mails accounts and I have over 15 email accounts in which you can see it all at once. I returned the Motorola and got my Mytouch 4g just two days ago and so far I'm loving it! I say so far because who knows what will pop up after playing with it for awhile like I did with the Motorola. Anyway, I checked the user reviews for this phone prior to purchasing and that the consensus was that it is a good phone but has couple of complaints such as speaker volume. Sure enough, after trying it out, the speaker is really poor compared to the Motorola I had. The Motorola had dual speakers and this Mytouch only has one so when you're in a semi-loud environment you really can't hear too well even the volume is up all the way. Another complaint was the face to face video calling but I haven't used it yet and I'm not that much concern about it since not too many people have that capability on their phones so I don't need that feature at this time. Otherwise, everthing else seems to work just fine. I love the camera with flash and the video recording comes with flash light so you can record in the dark! I will continue to update if I see anything else I need to mention as I get used to using this phone more.Edit: December 13th, 2010I've been using this phone now for little less than a month and I'm changing my opinion from loving it to just liking it. The things I really like about this phone so far are that what I mentioned before, camera and apps from Google. Also, this phone does allow you to create more than one email accounts from both Yahoo and Gmails. So I'm able to see it all at once since I have over 15 email accounts. It is, however, not as good as my iPhone 3G. It seems to be much slower in retrieveing all the emails compared to my iphone and it's not clear cut looking either. Ok here's the one MAJOR reason that I had to drop the star rating from 4 to 3 stars on this phone, and that is the battery life is ridiculously WEAK! I thought my iPhone 3g was weak but it still isn't that bad compared to Mytouch 4G! It is a pet-peeve of mine with a weak battery life on any phones, the CNET review says 4 to 5 hours of talking time but I really didn't even come close to using it that much. I tried using the battery saver apps such as killer apps and juice saver apps but none helped at all! I barely use it for no more than an hour of talking then did some internet surfing for couple of hours and my battery had drained more than 40%??? This is after fully charged! So now I have to charge this phone about twice a day if not more! I don't know if it's the battery that might be defected or not but it's a brand new phone and battery and I'm not about to go and spend another $40 for a new battery to see if it's defected or not. Another flaw detection is that when I am sending some old photos from my laptop to my emails so that I could downloaded to this phone's gallery but it wouldn't do it???!!! I never thought this would be an issue? This phone doesn't have a selection of which to download into the gallery format! So the photos are just stuck there in the format under the email I sent and if I need to view it, I have to open that email and view it from there. This is a major problem for me. I will keep this phone and will be purchasing iPhone 5G when it comes out next year.Edit: 12/18/10Previously I complained that there was no selection in downloading the pictures from the email to the gallery on the phone and that is still true. However, about couple of days later I found that the photos were there in the gallery??!! It took about few days before it actually got into the gallery? There obviously is some sort of delay effect. I'm happy that it did get to be downloaded into the gallery but it's annoying still to think that it took so long for it to do it. Strange. This is definitely a bug with this phone.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-19: The Lepow Modre Bluetooth Speaker fits in the palm of your hand but offers superb sound in such a miniscule size. With its unusual shape and variety of colors to choose from, there is sure a match for everyone.It arrived enclosed in a reusable cool hard plastic storage cup. It was extremely easy to pair with my iPhone 5S and did not require a pin or code. The included instructions come in several different languages and have a brief summary of how to pair and use the speaker. Controlling the volume and answering calls are all done via your phone. The only controls the speakers has is an on/off switch and the outputs for the charging and auxiliary port. The speaker has two very small LED lights to show the charge and Bluetooth status.Besides using it in Bluetooth mode you can also connect via an auxiliary cable. Connect your laptops, tablets, MP3 players or anything that has an headphone jack.With so many Bluetooth speakers out in the market today it can be a difficult job to pick one. The biggest factors to me are audio and visual appeal. The Modre has got my attention with its stylish good looks, amazingly crystal clear sound and ability to fill a modest size room like a bedroom, kitchen or office with great sound. The bottom of the speaker has a rubberized ring to keep it from sliding around.Solidly built and has one year warranty.Sample provided for review.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 3

    2014-06-29: 5 out of 5!!! It is aesthetically pleasing in terms of sound, looks, and design. It is easily connected via bluetooth and AUX. Pairing is painless and quick. I paired 3 of my phones with great ease. Look no further if you are looking for a portable speaker :)

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-12: Here my LePow's Modre Bluetooth Speaker review:Before reviewing the speaker, I would like to write a note about LePow's costumer service: they are really amazing, the best experience I have. Since one of my speakers came damaged they promptly send me a refund and my new order was sent in less than 2 days - Great!Now about the speaker:This little speaker has good quality and the sound is loud and enjoyable. They are ease to pair, the battery is long lasting, and they are really small so you can bring it with you everywhere you go.Having different brands of Bluetooth speaker under $100 I can classify them in following order:1) Braven 570 - The best sound in the list, open and clear with tight bass and soft treble, the mids are clear and very smooth. You have volume controls, hands free and a USB port to charge your phone in an emergency. Since the controls are in the right side of the speaker you have to get the speaker in your hands to use them. The Bluetooth range is great (30 feet). Price: around $100.2) LePow's Modre - Good sound, lack a bit of treble and bass, is very portable and has good construction. The only control available is the on/off at the speaker's bottom, you have to use your phone for volume and start hands free. The Bluetooth range is great (30 feet). Price: around $ 30.3) GoGroove BlueSYNC SRC - The sound is ok, but a little harsh in the treble and lacks some bass. Easy to pair, the controls works flawless and they are positioned on the speaker top, so they are very easy to access and to use. Price: around $304) Pyle PWPBT60 - The sound is ok, a lot of bass, but the mids and trebles are muffled. Lacks certain openness to the sound. They are sturdy, heavy, but have the worst Bluetooth connection. The connection drops all the time when someone or something is placed between the speaker and the phone, very annoying. The Bluetooth range is very limited. Price: around $70If you want a good sounding speaker that you can carry with you everywhere and don't want spend a lot of money, LePow's is the way to go. They come in a nice pack (a nice cup) with nice cables, they have a great design, very good construction. Enjoy !

    2014-04-03: I have quite a few Bluetooth speakers. Most are OK, but usually leave me wanting more. More bass, more clarity, more battery life, etc. Finally, I've found one with the perfect combination of everything! This Modre is stylish, sounds great, connects easy, and comes in great packaging. And, as an added bonus, the packaging doubles as a bass-booster. As I was listening to the Modre at my desk and admiring the plastic coffee-sippy cup it came in, on a whim I put the speaker back into it's packaging and it made the already good bass response even deeper. Ultimately, this is a solid, well-made product in a sea of mediocrity and yet it's priced very competitively, which makes it a winner in my book.

    2014-04-17: I've looked at a lot of Bluetooth speakers but this has got to be the prettiest. The presentation of this speaker is just great. First of all, it comes not in a box but in a cup. The cup is about 6 inches tall and has a silicone cover that matches the color of the speaker inside.When you open it, you get the speaker, a small instruction sheet, a USB cable and a 3.5mm audio cable. I received this speaker for review purposes.Bluetooth connection is a cinch. I didn't even have to read the instructions. I just turned on the power at the bottom and my smart phone found it right away. Once powered on, the sound is amazing. This speaker is only about 3.5 inches tall but the sound coming from it belies its size. This is one of the few times where form and function come together. I'm really impressed by this speaker and highly recommend it.

I shared this review with them and they immediately apologized for my dissatisfaction and offered to send another speaker. I was so impressed with this kind of customer service that I had to raise my review to 4 stars. I listened to the new speaker as well. I still feel the bass could be a little better but I did find a little trick. If you keep it in the cup it came in it does seem to enhance the sound a little. These are very quality made speakers which you will notice right away.

    2014-06-17: I recently moved thousands upon thousands of songs to the cloud and signed up for music streaming. So I started looking for speakers, specifically bluetooth speakers. This speaker produces a nice clear sound, although its size restricts it from producing any measureable bass. Volume is enough to fill a room and is clear even at the highest volume. This unit paired easily and does not lose connection to the device. My first unit had issues with the bluetooth dropping if you just waved your hand in between the devices. I contacted Lepow and they shipped me a new one immediately. They have excellent customer service and I would not hesitate recommending this product to friends and family. The new Modre does not lose connection and I can make it about 25ish feet without issue. I havent had the device on long enough to drain the battery as I normally play it while at work at lower volumes and then charge it overnight. It easily has played 6 hours without losing any quality whatsoever. I love the shape and size of the speaker and it makes a great portable speaker. I chose the green color and its a really great color. I know alot of people love the packaging but for me a normal/smaller carrying bag/case would of been preferred.Some things I am not fond of are that the unit does not have physical buttons to change the volume, or to answer calls. If you use the speaker during a phone call, people on the other end have issues hearing you unless you speak very loud. They also say it sounds as though you are in a tunnel. I didnt buy this speaker for talking on the phone, but since its a selling point, I thought I had to comment on it as well.I have a few other brands of bluetooth speakers coming in, so be sure to check my other reviews in the next week or two.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-01: This is the coolest portable Bluetooth speaker we have ever tested, and the sound it produces is outstanding! I like this speaker; it charges quickly, was easy to pair with our phones, plays great sound, and each charge lasts a long time. Very recommended.The Lepow Modre is much more than just a speaker as we were not only able to listen to great music, but we could use it as a speakerphone to handle incoming calls... all through the mic on the speaker's base! Very cool - well worth purchasing. The unit comes in multiple colors and the one we received was green. It came with a USB power cord that we plugged in to our Samsung phone's wall adapter, and the speaker fully charged in about 1.5 hours as indicated by the red charging light going out.The excellent instructions made it easy to pair with our phones, and pairing was quick and trouble-free with the speaker's voice prompt letting you know when pairing starts ("Pairing") and also when it is completed ("Pairing Completed"). That was a nice touch. The phone paired with the speaker was always within three to 12 feet of the speaker, typically one to eight feet away, with relatively good line of sight between the two devices. At no time did we experience distortion or loss of volume due to those distances.Tested with my Samsung Galaxy S3 and our teenage son's HTC Droid DNA, the first thing that we noticed was how well this speaker responded to the equalizers on those phones. The DNA has Dre Beats audio on-board, and man-o-man did this speaker rock with that program! When placed on the counter or tabletop, the impact on bass volume and resonance was outstanding.If you would like to see pictures of the speaker that I took, please go back to the speaker's main sales page, scroll down to where the "Most Helpful Customer Reviews" section starts, and look to the right of that area for the "Product Images From Customers" section. It really is a neat looking and great sounding device.We played an eclectic selection including Linkin Park, Everlast, Bob Marley and even a little B.B. King, from sources including Amazon's MP3 Cloud, Pandora and our own audio files. The results were outstanding; with a little tweaking from the equalizers for the different mixes of music, we coaxed the Lepow Modre speaker into producing superb sound for several hours. If I didn't have to concentrate to write this review, I would still be listening to the great tunes right this moment.While enjoying the music, we tested the inbound call capabilities and were impressed by the sound quality of the mic and the speaker during the call. I took a walk outside and placed a call to my son's phone; he answered the call and then spoke with me via the speaker -- and then we switched. Perfect device to use as an impromptu speakerphone!How many times have you purchased electronics and found that the user manual is just worthless? NOT the case here; the manual that comes with this speaker is well written and easy to follow, and has versions in more languages than I have ever seen come with such a device. Glad to see that time and care was put into creating a useful, well written guide.The speaker's retail carton, aka the cup, seems to be a novelty; thought maybe turning it upside down and placing the speaker on top of it would allow some special acoustic properties to shine through... but nope, the speaker sounds best when place on solid furniture.The User manual notes that there is a one year limited manufacturer's warranty, so if an issue arises before that period expires I will return here to update the review and let you know what the issue was and how resolution was handled. I did receive this speaker gratis from the manufacturer, and have put it through the paces to objectively find out how well it performed. My statements here reflect that testing.If you are looking for a speaker of this style, size and functionality, for use similar to what I have described above, then we highly recommend the Lepow Modre to you. Neat, funky, fun, easy to use, great sounds... really a nice unit.Go for it and enjoy.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-05: This Lepow Bluetooth speaker has a somewhat quirky design and comes in quirky packaging, too. That's not necessarily a bad thing. The speaker provides ample sound, but compared to my Philips SoundShooter, the bass is lacking in this speaker.PROs+ Loud speaker: much better than the speakers built into a phone+ The "Power On" voice is not obnoxiously loud, which is an issue with some other bluetooth speakers+ No volume controls: which I prefer as there is only one volume level I have to worry about messing with+ Physical on/off switch: no holding down a button and trying to figure out if it is on or not+ Micro USB charging: works with the chargers you likely already haveCONs- Level of bass is lacking, but sound quality is still good. However, I prefer the sound quality of the Philips SoundShooter over this device.- Portions of the instructions are in broken English, but it is fairly easy to figure out how to use this device

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-05: The first thing you notice about the Modre when you open the shipping box is the... odd packaging. It's quirky. It's fun. And highly unique.The Modre comes shipped in a travel style "cup." It's not really a travel mug as the rubber lid has no opening for liquid, but you can remove the sticker from the cup and all the packaging, give it a good wash and have a perfectly usable cup to go with your Modre. This kind of solution is quite brilliant in my mind, as if the person who receives the Modre keeps the cup, that's kept some worthless packing material out of the land fill or recycle bin. Of course, it will eventually need to be tossed, but in a few years I would hope, meaning you really are making a small difference.Anyway, the packing is brilliant. Hands down.The other things that stands out to me is the design of the speaker. I've tried out many... way too many... Bluetooth speakers. Each sounds OK and each has some unique design cue to it. The Modre is the first that seems to be designed with the thought of true 360 degree music. I can confirm, by dancing around the speaker as it blares my music that the experience is, pretty much, the same in front as it is from behind the speaker.The performance itself is about what I've come to expect from a BT speaker. It sounds OK. It's not audiophile quality, and if that's what you are looking for in this price range you are deluding yourself for sure (it won't happen). Instead, if you lower your standards a tiny bit, you can jump into the Modre and enjoy truly portable, easily portable as the weight is minimal, BT audio from your speakers.It also includes a mic so that you can use the Modre as a speaker phone. My only complaint is that there are no controls on the device to answer the phone or change volume. That's a minor complaint given the performance and fun level.I used BT, which was simple to connect to my Lumia 1020 and my iPhone (don't ask why I have 2 phones). I also plugged the speaker into my computer using the line out. Sound is good out of the box. If you want a deeper bass experience, or tighter treble, plug the speaker into your computer or connect it via BT to your computer and use a program, such as J River Media Center, that allows you to do custom EQ. After EQ the sound is quite good. And no, I don't expect EQ capability on a portable speaker at this price, just pointing out that a little EQ can go a long way.Overall:I am quite happy with the Modre. The packaging is silly, quirky and fun. This is the first time I've mentioned PACKAGING in a speaker review for a BT speaker.Performance, for the price, is quite nice. With a little EQ, you get a great sound but unfortunately not all phones off that kind of capability.With the ability to plug the included 2.5mm plug into a device that doesn't have BT support, you can still enjoy the sound from the Modre and your chosen device.Highly recommended.I received a free sample from the manufacturer for review purposes. I would NOT hesitate to spend money on a Lepow product. Bar none.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-03: This little baby puts out good amount of volume, with nice clarity and not much muddiness to the sound. For the price I paid, great buy.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 3

    2012-11-25: Based on the title ("Nokia 02732Q6 HH-23 PureView 808 Tripod Mount") you would think that Nokia has designed this mount for the PureView 808, but it's a much more generic thing. It feels cheaply built and gives the expectation that after a dozen or so uses it'll probably break (I've only used it a couple of times so far). It also provides a somewhat tenuous grasp on the 808, which is a relatively bulky phone.Use of it takes some care; to avoid pushing buttons, you have to place it in a very specific area between the slider for the screen unlock and the shutter button; in this spot it obstructs the slider so you want to unlock the screen first, then try to install the phone in the mount without touching the screen. It doesn't give a confidence-inspiring grip, so use with caution.

    Rating: 2

I will be interested to see how well my phone stays in mount while out in the field. The physical mount is very small, but it feels very sturdy.

    2012-09-13: This is exactly what I was looking for. I wanted another genuine Samsung battery for my S II, and the charging pack plus AC adapter was a bonus. On eBay, "genuine Samsung" batteries for $5 tend to be knock offs and I really don't trust that in my phone. Amazon sells this for half the price T-Mobile wants and it came in genuine Samsung packaging.Let's face it, smartphones these days tend to only last one full day, so if you forget to plug it in before going to sleep, you're left with a nearly dead phone. This battery/charger kit lets me pop a new battery in before I leave the house, and let my dead one charge during the day. Yes, I have a car charger, and yes, I have an extra home charger -- but who wants to be tethered to a charger? So much more convenient to pop a new battery in.

    Rating: 5

    2012-02-17: This is a great deal for the price. My only complaint is that the charge cable is 0.7A rather than 1.0A. This means that it will take (on average) an extra hour or two to charge the battery to full. Easily solved by using a 1.0A charge cable, but I think it should have come with the package.

    Rating: 4

    2012-03-08: I had this same device for my Samsung Vibrant. I find that having the battery charger and an extra battery is very useful. Normally, I'd have 3 batteries total: one in the phone, an extra charged battery in my purse, and one battery charging in the charger. Rotate as needed. This setup is particularly helpful when going on travel, since you don't have to worry about your phone running down and not being able to access an electrical outlet to charge it up. You simply swap batteries and keep going.I ordered mine from Direct Wireless. The charger came in its original retail box, unopened. The charger and all accessories appeared new and unused, as expected. It works, I am happy!

The holder is just that, a holder. No usb power hookup so when your phone is on the holder it sits there.. only the battery in the back will charge.When its charging the light is red, when its done it turns green. i assume this turns off the charging and i can leave the battery on there but im not sure?anyways, its great. I get nervous with micro/mini usb always plugging/unplugging... now i dont need to.. the case has a power supply always plugged into it and i can just swap batteries.buying another one so i have one at home and one at work.Updated: bought my 2nd one and haven't looked back. love it!also, i have a case on my phone and the holder still works!i recomend this for EVERY skyrocket user! extra battery + charger + holder!

    Rating: 4

    2012-01-13: Bought this for those long days on the golf course when using my Samsung Galaxy S2 Skyrocket for GPS yardage marking. We all know that GPS drains our phones at a rapid rate, so having the extra fully charged battery gives me peace of mind that I will have enough power to make a phone call if needed after the round. The stand is coonvenient to use on your night stand if you use your phone as an alarm clock, it will stand securely vertically or horizontally. However the one con I can think of is that it doesn't have the ability to charge your phone while docked on the stand. It would've been perfect if you could wake up to a fully charged phone and extra battery while in the stand. The only way I've figured out how to charge both batteries at the same time is to have one battery charging in the charger/stand, and then have the phone in the stand either horizontal or upside down so that your original travel charger can still be plugged into the phone over night. Still, I reccommend this for anyone who may have long days on the weekends(during the weekdays I just keep plugged into my computer at work so it is always fully charged).

    Rating: 4

  • B00EF1OGOG

    $B00EF1OGOG

    2014-02-22: This is such an upgrade from the previous generation. It is slightly bigger/heavier (only mentioning it but it's hardly noticeable) but it also provides more recharge capability. It was able to fully recharge my iPhone 5 from 10% to 100% in about 40 minutes. The recharge rate could be better but you can also continue using your device while it's recharging so no harm no foul. I gave it only 4 stars because it seems the "firm" flick to display the currently charge capacity is more like a minor vibration. If you carry this in your pocket, or anywhere else on your person, that display will be on constantly. Not a major issue but I don't like my battery banks using it's charge for anything less than charging my device. The first generation had a similar issue with the flashlight accidentally turning on which killed the charge as well. Overall though a VERY nice product.

    Rating: 4

    2014-02-28: This thing is so handy, and it charges my iPhone multiple times. I am out and about a lot, so having a back up battery really saves me. So far this product works really well and I am extremely happy with it.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-14: Ordered this battery to charge my iPhone 5s and my girlfriend's GS3 when we travel. It does the job well get at least one full charge for both phones. The design is great love the feel and the little pouch that comes with it. One huge caveat for me; I cannot stand the fact that the shake to reveal battery level feature is so easily activated. I mean this thing would come on inside my backpack or in my pocket while I was on the move. Its so annoying and I can't help but feel like I am definitely loosing some power when this gets activated. Seriously just walking with this thing it would light up and show me the battery level all the time. I find this incredibly aggravating and if and when I am in the market to buy another battery I would not buy another Anker external battery with this feature. This was my concern when I bought this battery and I should have listened to my first instinct.

    Rating: 2

    2014-04-28: I had to return this battery for one reason: it doesn't support pass-through charging (AKA passive charging). So if you want to charge this battery while at the same time charging another device from this battery, look elsewhere. I need this feature because I'll be using my USB battery pack as a cache battery between my bicycle's dynamo hub and my smartphone. I ended up buying the Limefuel 6000 mAh battery, which definitely does support pass-through charging.

    2013-11-06: I used this to charge my Galaxy S2 while doing a backpacking trip in Texas. I was running the GPS all day to both track my hike and set way points for future reference.     2013-10-17: It's light weight enough so can keep it in my pocket when I go to theme parks but packs enough juice to charge my phone two times over.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-05: Short Summary: Just like the 9000mAh. Too Gimmicky. Lack of design function, too much form consideration. Bit higher efficiencyAs I mentioned in my 9000mAh review for this pack, my ideal battery pack is as follows:1) Lightweight2) Economically priced3) Small footprintAnything additional addon or design to the battery back is impractical. It serves more of a distraction than usefulness. Plus as consumers, we will pay more to have these "features" that we do not need.Features (2/10):This goes the same for this 6000mAh pack. We want functional features on our products, not gimmicky features.The Shake to Wake function serves more a gimmick than any practical useFirstly so call shake requires a considerable force. Not many people will be willing to throw their arms frantically to get this awake. Can get this slipped out from your hand and there goes your battery. Consider I have both 9000mAh and 6000mAh, it's not a coincidence shake to wake problem is just a one off.Since the shake function is gimmicky and serves zero practically, it's simple to say we are paying more money for useless feature while having motors inside to make the battery pack weight more.Performance (8/10):Here is where it's better than the 9000mAh function with a slightly higher, but still subpar inefficency.Performance is still less at what a regular external battery does.There's a simple math formula to calculate power conversion.In my one week of trial, I'm able to get 1.5 recharge on my Galaxy S3 which is 2100mAh. This means in actual fact this is 3300mAh after efficiency conversionThe Wh claimed here is 6A*3.7V=22.2Wh22.2Wh/5V (5V from USB) = 44.4A*1000=4440mAh is the expected Wh without circuit board inefficiency for a 6000mAh battery pack3300mAh (from actual use) / 6600mAH = 0.7524 equals to 75.24% power conversion efficiency through their circuit board. Average total energy conversion rate (TECR) on average circuit board is rated at 80-85% from reputable brands.This equals to around 5-10% less energy efficient than your typical reputable brand with the same battery they are using. This is better than the 9000mAh battery pack but still off from the usual standardAs mentioned previously, 3 problems can cause issue:1) cheap battery used2) cheap board design causing inefficiency3) cheap material used on circuit board reducing TECRWith multi cell design batteries, it's easy to slip in an occasionally lower rating batteries while having another one at full capacity. It's negligible to some people but over the years, the amount of battery capacity you lost do build up. Imagine using this 500 times, losing 10% of 500 time is still 50 times lost charge that shouldn't have occurred in the first place.Cheap board design occurs when manufacturer uses poorly made board or power inefficient chips. This caused lose of energy and greatly reduce the TECR as I mentioned earlierPrice (2/10):Again, this is not cheap for its performance result. Some brand carry a 6000mAh battery as low as 17 dollars. At literally more than double the price than other comparable brands, this manufacturer is making a massive margin and justify adding more cost by:1) putting gimmick features on board2) possibly using mediocre battery cells3) possibly using cheap material or poor board designWith more cheaper alternatives out there with higher efficiency. With more choices out there, it's hard to find reason to pay this much for a battery packDesign(3/10):I will say the same for this battery as I did with the 9000mAh. The overall aesthetic of the battery is nice to look but lacks practicality. People need to note that for backup battery pack, function is far more important than how it looks. Concept of design requires a good balance between function and form with polarized products such as a backup battery pack, it requires much more function over form.In the case where you will hold this backup battery with your phone or tablet, the rounded surface leaves your phone or tablet unstably settled. As a product of support, it is unfortunately not supportive at all.That itself is a design failure and lack of consideration to real user experience.Conclusion (2/10)We probably want something more practical, more functional when it comes to higher price.. Aesthetic is great on some products but as far as a real support product is concerned, this battery pack, again, has too much glitter and glamour but none of the practical stuff you really need. It's a support device for your phone and it is the phone where the glitter and glamour should be. However, it's not acting like a support device at all with its subpar performance and its rounded surface.Honestly a flat design will work much better to hold this along with the phone but most likely it will be better to sit in somewhere you don't require it to be stationary. If you find my review useful, please vote Yes. Thanks for reading!

    Rating: 3

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-24: Great looking and performing product. The items exterior is glossy and smooth to the touch. It is a little heavy but then it's a 6000 mAh battery pack so that was expected. The small form factor of the battery pack was suprizing though. It is small engough to fit in the size of your hand which makes it extremely portable (pockets, purses, etc). I do really like the features of the battery back, battery level LED divided into 10 sections that shows the current power left, smart USB port and the shake to turn on feature.Items in the box:* The Anker 2nd Gen Astro 6000 mAh battery* Instruction manual* 12in USB charging cable* Carrying bag to protect the powerbank* Compatibility to use your own cable for chargingFeatures:*USB Smart port (will detect the device and charge at max output for the device)*Shake to turn it on and see battery level*To charge just plug into an outlet or computer USB port* LED battery level display showing either 90%, 80%, 70%, 60%, 50%, 40%, 30%, 20%, 10% and 0%*About 80% charged when you recieve itCon:The serial number is on the cable itself versus the powerbank. It doesn't affect the usuage of the device but it does make more sense to have it on the device itself.Devices tested on: iTouch, iPhone, iPad, Samsung Tab, Galaxy S4 without issue.Tested with charging the iPhone and to fully charge the iPhone about 25% battery life on the battery pack was used.Device Battery Capacity. (This chart is to give you a rough idea of the number of times you can recharge your device with the 6000mAh powerbank from Anker.)* iPhone 4 Battery (1420 mAh)* iPhone 4S Battery (1432 mAh)* iPhone 5 Battery (1434 mAH)* iPad 2 Battery (6944 mAh)* iPad 3 Battery (11560 mAh)* iPad 4 Battery (11486 mAH)* iPad Mini Battery (4490 mAH)* Kindle Fire Battery (4400 mAh)* Kindle Keyboard Battery (1750 mAh)* PlayStation Portable 3000 Battery (1500 mAh)* BlackBerry Torch 2 9810 Battery (1270 mAh)* Nintendo 3DS Battery (1300mAh)Overall outstanding item and I'm very impressed. I would recommend this to anyone who wants the latest tech gadget out there. As of now this is the most feature rich powerbank that I have seen and own. The Smart USB port is also really useful as some devices only charge at 1A and some at 2A. The Smart USB port allows you to use the same port to charge both 1A and 2A devices and at the max current allowed. Great for having a backup plan to charge your portable device on the go.I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation in order to provide a fair and honest review.

    2014-01-13: This very portable 6000mAh ultra slim charger (with built in flashlight) is very high powered and even has a built in VERY BRIGHT flashlight. This unit I have tried on my Samsung Galaxy phone and on my Samsung Galaxy Player. Since I carry around a tablet and a phone, what I do is charge one and get it fully charged and then place the other into this so that each one stays charged and ready to go. Note that this comes with two USB charging cables, neck strap, hand strap, and excellent instruction manual. Below you will see my testing results and suggestions:+ My Testing Results on Charger: Each device charged up VERY QUICKLY from 50 percent to 100 percent in just 1.5 hours! Therefore you can purchase that is full confidence because it has a FULL 2amps, which is just what most newer tablets require for the fastest charge! And it also benefits newer and larger phones (such as the S4) because it charges just about as fast as their wall connection counterparts!+ My Testing Results on Flashlight – To fully test this, I went into a very large and totally dark closet and turned on the flashlight part. WOW! Everything in the closet as vivid. Then I went outside in a dark area of my yard, shined the flashlight and I could see very well, in fact just as well as my big and bulky regular flashlight (now retires)!+ Do you need a high powered portable charger with a flashlight (but just need one port)? Then I will suggest this to you as it will charge your tablet or phone very fast. However, there is ONE port. If you are looking for one like this WITH 2 PORTS with 2 amp, with a flashlight also, then I suggest to you the EasyAcc Power Bank 9000 (which I also own and have reviewed). The Anker Power Bank 9000 has dual ports for your tablet and for your phone and also a Flashlight!     2013-10-20: OK, it's an external battery. Everybody makes one. But no one makes one this "sexy". It's designed to provide portable power that meets the needs of today's high draw electronics, and still be a great tactile and visual experience. It's sized to fit in a pocket or a bag without taking up more room than your phone. No switch to worry about, just a shake and the segmented charging indicator shows the power left. And it pulses when actively charging. No need to hide this one, it works and looks great.On the practical side, my old Galaxy S 2 has a 1800 mAh battery and I get 4+ charges from the battery. However, I use this mostly to keep the phone working (radios off, of course) on plane trips. I fly 4-6 legs per week, and use the phone for video, audio, etc. This keeps the phone fully charged and ready for use when I get to an airport. I've also used this as a power source for a Lenovo Tablet, Nook Color, Jawbone, and JamBox with excellent results.Anker has great customer support, product quality, and an 18 month warranty. It also comes with a short micro USB cable for recharging battery and charging compatible devices. Also included is a sturdy bag made of netting and a locking drawstring. Makes it easy to find in the dark. This is another well designed Anker product at a great price.

    2014-06-11: First of all the battery is very sleek. I like the incremental led light in the front and the fact that there are no buttons you simply pick it up and it turns on and lights up to display the charge. It is compact enough to fit in your pocket so you could charge your phone on the go easily. I charged my phone up to full and the leds did not even go to halfway so i know this thing is raited as it claims. It also charges pretty fast. I noticed after a long charge it does not get hot or even warm to the touch. My cheap external battery i have gets burning hot.So all in all i would consider it a great product. It seems smaller than comparable 6000mah battery packs. I like the fact it is able to detect the product you are trying to charge and bump up to the amperage automatically such as phone vs a tablet.If you are looking for a portable battery this is THE ONE to get. Stop looking at other ones and brands. Heck for the price nothing even compares.I paired this with the Anker 1A usb wall charger to make sure i always charge it properly to ensure a long life.

    2014-07-02: I get about 1.5 charges on my iPhone 5s, which is about what I expected. I don't need it often -- just days when I'm on the road all day and go hard on the phone. I'll use it, get home that night and plug it in over night, and it holds the charge again until I need it a week or two later. And it looks good. I like that. I can't attest to it's usefulness on tablets or laptops, but you should probably buy a higher mAh for those devices.

    2014-06-20: Why buy a charger like this rather than a spare battery? Well, it depends. If you have a protective case like an Otter, replacing the battery might be difficult and time consuming. This spare charger is really fast and easy. Of course if you have a phone with a sealed battery, you won't have another option but a portable charger. Lastly, if you have a phone that has battery change access and you use a holster without a case, a spare battery is probably a better option.When I need a charger, a battery for a cell phone I always buy Anker. The quality of their products is always excellent and while I have never needed their service, their reputation is second to none. You could order an OEM battery and end up with a counterfeit or another brand that won't work right out of the box. I prefer Anker, you get what you pay for. This charger is excellent, buy without any concern whatsoever. Highly recommended.
