    2011-12-28: My DroidX broke, but usual story: I'm not up for a discounted phone for a few mos. So I picked up the Pixi+ to use until then. I wanted something a little simpler, but not too simple like a basic phone.Count me as another "new, accidental" user who previously gave little thought to WebOS, now a little disappointed that it's barely hanging on. I only picked up the Pixi+ because of my situation, and I thought it would just be neat to try something different for the time being. Wow, it has a neat and intuitive interface. While the phone obviously can't do what the DroidX does by way of features and apps, I really like the card-and-swipe UI (disclaimer: the Homebrew patches help to make it much better).I really like the launcher and icons (better than what I've seen on the iPhone). And I finally realize that I need a "real" keyboard. I had to correct almost every individual word on the touch-screen keyboard of my Android, which was probably the most frustrating thing of all for me (I realize some Android phones have keyboards). And I did try other keyboard apps.I never would have gotten the Pixi had my phone not broken because it looks a little cheap and ugly (to me) in the pictures. But now that I have it, the keyboard and form factor are great, other than maybe the smallish screen.There are a few things I can't get to work as I'd like. The AIM simply won't log in (it's probably outdated). The music skips a little too frequently due to the slow processor (even overclocked). And I can't get Navi to work for me. You're not going to get Google Sky Maps on here. But for the basics, some things are better than what I had on the DroidX (IMO). The email works way better (even Gmail). the notifications banners are really nice. I like the browser experience simply because of the swipe and bookmark list -- it's just easy. The calendar is nicer and works better. List/note apps and other things are more convenient. Everything is "right there" with no complications swiping apps open, closed, and between several running apps at once. YouMail is better. Deleting things like email, vmail messages, bookmarks, etc is all swipe-easy. Even my Gmail contacts seem to link better. With the Homebrew patches, this thing holds its own even on an old OS / phone. So even with an older phone and less features, I find that I really like it better overall.Lastly, the Pixi+ transitions seamlessly between Wifi and 3G. I've had no issues so far (after several weeks) unlike with my Android phone.It's too bad WebOS wasn't bought by a company that could support it, or at least incorporate it into its current ecosystem. But it is what it is.

    Rating: 4

    2011-03-17: I was about to return this phone because Verizon wanted a $45 data plan just to activate it; then I read the brilliant comments by Chuck Homic.Opening the package, I saw the ESN/MEID HEX printed on the box. I held down the power button until the PALM light lit up on-screen. It took a while for it to boot up. The phone tried twice to call Verizon and activate itself, to no avail.On another phone, I called the Page Plus Cellular toll-free number and gave them the Pixi's MEID and the phone number that I wanted ported from my active, prepaid Verizon phone. They gave me a 'Premier Package' 6-digit activation code to dial from Pixi, and said that Verizon is usually quick to release your old number and to call back when they have done so.It took about an hour or so that the old cell number stopped ringing the old phone, indicating that it had been ported.In order to dial the activation code on the Pixi, you first press the little phone symbol on the screen and press Emergency Call. When the dialpad shows, hit the backspace three times to erase the 911 off the screen. Enter the six-digit code and hit the Call button. The phone will take a while to activate and will need to be rebooted when it's finished.After you reboot the phone, you'll have to do the Phone Symbol- Emergency Call- erase 911- thing again. Now on the dialpad, try to call a phone number near you to test, like a home number or something. When the phone near you rings, hang up and listen for the confirmation on the phone that it's working.IMPORTANT: Page Plus Cellular gives your account about $2 worth of phone/ text/ data to start your service. Because the Palm Pixi Plus requires a data connection to set up the Palm Profile and activate FIRST, you cannot use WiFi yet to do this. The $2 credit should be plenty to just set up your profile; if not, then call them from another phone and make sure you get the full-on Premier activation code.When I was told this, and since I only use the Voice feature for rare 'emergency' and 'notice' calls, then I opted for the Standard Plan of $10 for 100 minutes that expire after 120 days ($30/year).After the Palm Profile was set up, a brief video tutorial ensued. I then immediately tapped on the Signal Bars symbols to turn on the WiFi, and entered my router's WPA security code for access to my home WiFi network.Now using my own WiFi, I felt FREE to import/ associate the Pixi with my Google contacts, emails, and calendar. Sweet.Here are my notes on this - [Amazon took away the link to my SpringPad notes - [...] ]UPDATE: I've put 380+ songs on it, plus the Pandora App, and I still have 5gb of space.The 'Amazon MP3' app is already built in. The music sounds so good that I ordered the Palm headset as well. I also like the AccuWeather app and about 16 others.UPDATE: I got the dedicated Palm stereo headset for about $3 and discovered that double-clicking the Mic Mute button will advance to the next song (FF) - see review:Palm Stereo Headset for Palm Pixi and Palm Pre. At that price, I try to keep a pair in the car, work, etc.UPDATE: I got a deal on the Belkin Bluetooth dongle for Home Stereo -NEW Version Belkin F8Z492-P Bluetooth Music Receiverand so that I could play my music on the Pixi over my full system; I really like that.UPDATE: plugging and unplugging the charge cord was starting to be a chore, so I bought the TouchStone inductive charger from Palm where you just lay the phone on top of the thing -Palm Touchstone Charging Dock for Palm Pre and Palm Pixi. You have to use a special jacket w/ the TouchStone, and I chose one in bright orange -Palm Pixi Touchstone Cover (orange)UPDATE: THE HOLY GRAIL FOUND -- 'Mark' commented on Chuck Homic's post on Jun 16, 2011 - how to keep voice calls coming in while shutting off cellular data usage but still allowing for WiFi data flow:Mark says -"Mobile hotspot is *not* the only way to consume data. The phone will try to use data silently in the background for you. But you can make it so that it won't do it via carrier data. Open up the phone app (the green phone handset icon), swipe down on the upper left hand menu and select "Preferences and Accounts". A new card will come up. Scroll to the bottom and you should see something labled "Data Usage". Set that to "OFF". This will also extend your battery life on the phone by quite a bit.""If you really want to use the background data features of the phone - called "Synergy" - enable wifi and connect to your home wifi network."Thanks, Mark

    Rating: 5

    2011-03-30: Ah I had to return the phone the guy did refund my money, so I can not say anything bad about him but the phone was reported lost, I could not activate it it became useless to me, so I then contacted him and mailed the phone back the next morning, along with a tracking number something he never provided me with I like to do good business he says he did not know the phone was report lost or stolen but that is his problem not mine.I returned it and I am done, I am not using products that are hot, if you want something new purchase new I purchased from Closeout Masters.     Rating: 1

    2011-10-02: I am writing this review just after purchasing my second palm pixi (for my daughter) and am thinking quite seriously about a 3rd & 4th. It is a terrific phone for what I paid: $36 from the OEM shop (notated as there are several different marketplace sellers). My experience was very good, phone arrived fast, and new (other reviewers commented on having trouble activating used phones). The package included a wall charger and usb charger.I'd like to thank many reviewers who pointed to pageplus! what a fantastic deal, and very nice people too. Regards activation, it took a bit more time as the msin # was not on the box and had to be retrieved from inside the phone, under the battery (not a huge issue, just took a bit of extra time). I will also note that the 12 cents left after activation is *before you put any money in*. After activation I had just over 100 minutes, ample time to check the phone/ service/ coverage; all very good.Back to the phone itself: as one with many (too many) cell phones... mostly from bad experience; poor service/ coverage etc I would compare this favorably to every other phone I have bought in this price range (e.g. the lg620gLG 620G Prepaid Phone (Net10)which is an adequate phone, but nowhere near as nice or fully featured as this phone. I would also compare it favorably to the motorola razor (not a very smart or solid phone) as well as several basic Nokias. The pixi is an early smart phone (as in pre-android). It has PDA features (contacts, task list) implemented as cards (basically ap icons) an MP3 & video player, which unlike on some other phones/ services, you can add your own music to my dragging & dropping. It also has a button to connect to Amazon's MP3 store. The phone has "synchrony" to connect to google, MS outlook and palm's website, which brings me to one important feature I *really dislike* : Your info will be stored on Palm's server. I personally hate the intrusion on privacy and am hoping for legislation to contain it. But, this is something you should know. It will limit how I use my phone! There are friends who also value their privacy... I can not will not put them in my contact list, so that cripples the phone somewhat for me. I also will not use an organizer function which posts my appointments to any web site. I am a psychologist, (there are real ethical issues here). I am hoping this is not a trend. If it is, I will be buying up last gen phones rather than succumb to the intrusion.The phone also has a web browser (verizon's implementation) email connects, as well as popular social networking sites.My complaints with this phone are few and mostly related to Verizon; the documentation is minimal at best (e.g. to transfer music, drag & drop... it does not say where. I put different songs in the phone window, and created a music folder within it, both were picked up by the MP3 player). I have not yet figured out if I can create ringtones on it, but know, at least that I can import them (some phones block this, forcing you to buy from the service). The user guide has more information on how to use gestures, unique to this platform, than other aps. or even the physical phone (when I needed to remove the battery to activate, there was no info on how to open the phone...) It was fairly simple, and info available out on the web, but why was it not included in the user manual? It seems the manuals (3 included) are more about disclainmers & safety warnings (don't listen to your music too loud, throw your battery in a fire: good one, submerge in water... so it is a process of discovery, finding out what all of the features are. It is not a complicated phone to figure out or use, but reasonable documentation is nice. Some of us *do* read the manual ;)In brief: This is a great phone for what it is currently selling for. You can use it as a prepaid phone on cdma networks. It is a smart (not android) phone with PDA functions, a browser, MP3 and video player, a camera (which I forgot to mention earlier) which also shoots video (not very high quality, but then none of them are) and some features which can make set up etc easier for some as it uses synchronicity to pull down your contacts, to do lists... from other sites (if you give it permission). It also has aps and google maps on board (you have to enable google snoop to use them).cons:Poor documantation/ user manuals, no memory expansion (but a good amount on board), have to agree to Palm's terms of use which will pick up information you enter. (Note: other "features" require giving permission to various services, but those can be denied, Palm's can not). I personally do not like being tracked or having my personal info distributed, sold... and will always opt-out. Fortunately most of these decisions are put in your hands (so you can opt to use google maps if you permit google, e.g. I have several of these features turned off or crippled on my phone, but still think it is a terrific phone for what it costs; best I have found so far.

    Rating: 5

    2011-07-19: description should tell all --- not Palm's best work -- freezes way too often -- says 8 gb memory but you get error message after error message saying toss cards too many apps open. Battery good for 11 hours then dead, screen scratches easily and since its glass dont drop it from 2 feet or else.     Rating: 1

    2011-09-14: The phone I bought was sold through BlueTek USA. It looked used. The back cover was dirty, not in plastic, had greasy smudges on it from fingers, and the part above the USB port was broken.Now on to the phone review:The initial boot-up took a few minutes which is ypical of most smartphones, especially old ones with slow processors. Once it booted up, I was prompted to activate the phone with Verizon Wireless. I shut the phone off, went to my account page on Verizon's website, activated the phone, then started over again.After activation, I was prompted to create a Palm account. The first thing I noticed was how cramped and sludgy feeling, yet clicky the keyboard is. The second thing I noticed was how slow this thing is. But I wasn't expecting much from a smartphone with a 600mhz processor. Seriously though, when I tried to change my ringtone, it took 5-10 seconds for the phone to gather and display the ringtones. "Seconds" doesn't usually indicate a long time, but compare it to any smartphone released in the past year and it'll seem slow.Once initial setup was completed, a walkthrough began to play which demonstrated how to use the phone's gestures. What looks like dead space/useless bezel between the keyboard and the screen is actually a touch panel for back, forward, and up gestures which feeds back with a soothing, glowing strip of light.Web OS is pretty nice though. I like the way multitasking works and it's fairly simple to use with little learning curve. If you want to search for an installed app, search the web, or search for an address or business, just start typing and a card will appear which lets you choose Google, Google Maps, Wikipedia or Twitter. Adding custom ringtones and wallpapers is refreshingly easy; Similar to Android devices, you can plug the phone in, choose "USB Storage" and just drag your wallpaper images into the "Wallpapers" folder, and ringtones and notification sounds into the "Ringtones" folder.Overall, the phone looks cute and fits nicely in the pocket. The soft back cover is nice (I prefer soft touch to glossy plastic or even glass). It's a functional device that will provide you with entertainment, information and communication on the go. There is an app store and some widely used apps are available (Evernote, Pandora, Accuweather, a Twitter app, Facebook, Angry Birds, etc). And even though pretty much every smartphone has it, the mobile hotspot functionality comes in handy (if you pay for it).Despite it's crappy 2MP camera, fixed 8GB of storage (that's right, no MicroSD card slot) tiny, low quality screen (but at least it's glass and capacitive) and tiny keys, it's worth buying since it's only $40 off-contract here on Amazon. If HP didn't give up on WebOS and Palm devices, it would probably cost at least $250. So, it's not a bad deal. The only reason I bought it was for the price. I sold my iPhone 4 months ago and have been using a basic cell phone. I missed having an mp3 player, map, camera, casual game player and web browser on me. I'm not eligible for an upgrade for another year, I can't spend $500+ on a new phone at full retail, and I'm sick of sketchy Craigslist sales and used phones with scratched displays, caked up skin flakes and dirt in the crevices, and lingering cologne/perfume odors. Honestly, I was pleasantly surprised with WebOS. But the OS and the device itself are lacking - A LOT - and if there was a faster, better WebOS phone available for a typical smartphone retail price, I wouldn't buy it.Most people replace their smartphones within a year or two, so the fact that HP gave up on WebOS isn't that big of a deal. Just don't expect a ton of updates and support. The phone has 3-4 year old hardware anyway. If you're in a similar situation as I am (i.e., too poor to buy a new phone off contract, but not too poor to pay your share of a family account) or want a pre-paid phone, it's not a bad purchase. I could also see this being useful for someone who has an expensive smartphone but wants a second device when there may be a risk of losing or damaging their good phone.Too bad I couldn't get a Touchpad when the liquidation happened. That would have been nice. It's cool how they transfer links and other data. I ordered one from OnSale through Amazon. They took way more orders than they could fill and cancelled a ton of them after holding everyone's money for a few days. That sucked.

    Rating: 3

    2011-07-10: I very much appreciated the review that talked about getting a Pixi Plus, using only WiFi, staying off of Verizon by signing up with a reseller like Page Plus--everything is working so far in terms of "free" e-mail, web, etc. access as long as I'm near WiFi (at home and work, mostly). My old Palm PDA was dying, and this has been a great replacement.The only regret I have is that a few apps from the past aren't available on the newer operating system of the Pixi Plus (HanDbase, for example); other than that (and the need to charge this every night!!), I'm quite satisfied so far.

    Rating: 4

    2011-06-05: At this point,(I have only had this cell phone a month now) I feel it is becoming one of the best devices I have ever bought. The last Palm device I bought at Amazon with paying full freight, was the Palm TX, a big disappointment. Taught me a great lesson, never pay full retail for electronics again, the price will drop even if it's older technology. As a result Palm lost me for many years as a customer after being a long time user. Until now. Could not resist this device at $56,which AT&T; sells unlocked for hundreds. Web OS is one of the slickest OS's ever encountered outside iPhone/touch, having no experience with Androids can't comment. Hardware is good, resolution very good, ringer volume on the low side but acceptable for me.If you follow previous comments on how to activate the phone sans Verizon(see Chuck Homic,he is the reason I went for it(the method described worked superbly), it's the best bargain out there in the world of smartphones. Cellular portion of the phone I rarely use(though that works excellently), I mainly wanted it for it's wi-fi capabilities, and that's free. In a sense it's like an iPod touch with a cell phone attached. With Kitty wireless you can get good deals on pins and texting, good small company to deal in tandem with Pageplus, with all your cell phone needs. $30 dollars a year to keep the phone active, is a huge message to the big carriers that there are cheap alternatives, if you are willing to deal with not having the latest rage device, this is one heck of a phone, in a class of it's own.Not a big gabber on the phone, so the low volume on incoming calls didn't bother me too much, you can always wear a headset, no mic needed. Lots of complaints over screen size, it's no bigger or smaller than most BlackBerry's out there I believe, when navigating web sites you do have to really pinch and zoom and double tap a lot. You can use iTunes or windows media to sort of organize your stuff on the phone itself. Just drag iTunes music directly in to the device, you can use Windows Media Player, or in my case, Windows explorer drag and drop. Options galore.The only minor complaint I have is the the ringer and speaker volume could be louder. I basically use this as my MP3 player and hearing the ringer with a headset is plenty loud, but being in a loud environment trying to hear a ringer might be a bit difficult, vibrate only works with one pulse and it's over. But the phone portion is not that critical for me, remember Verizon network has the least amount of dropped calls, which is comforting.The browser and the synergy gathering of your email accounts work very well, overall an outstanding deal, I'm happy. At this price buy 2 or more for gifts. They'll love you.

    Rating: 5

    2012-09-17: I like almost everything about this phone. I like having a smartphone that is inexpensive, small, has a physical keyboard, and can do all the important tasks like make calls, send texts and emails, and surf the internet. I don't care that much about processor speed, apps, etc. This phone costs almost nothing and does everything I need it to, on an OS that I think is better the iOS or Android (WebOS is very intuitive and easy to use and Apple copied a lot of ideas from it).The problem is that the quality of this phone is so bad. The cover starts peeling apart after a few months of normal, light use. I the touch screen stopped working. It made a weird wailing noise every time it received an incoming call (even with the ringer on silent). It's just a shame because I don't want to carry around a huge Android phone and I don't want to fork over a ridiculous premium for an iPhone. But after my second Palm Pixi falling apart, it's just not worth it to get another one. Too bad.

    2011-06-10: Overall, the OS is ok. You have to use USB cable to connect to computer, THEN delete the file! There is no "window explorer" or anything similar to go the the proper file directory to delete the file. WTH!?!!! even BB and Windows mobile 5 and 6 can do it back in 2007. Can Palm do any better?Update #2: Somehow my hotspot didn't work anymore. The only thing that I hadn't done is hard-resting. On the Backup menu, it stated that "Your data is backup automatically every day." So, I took it that it really does that. However, I am SO wrong about it. It is NOT. I hard reset per VZ representative instructed. Yes, I got the hotspot working again. However, the data is not backed up!! I am talking just the contact info, not even the memo and txt. And the phone becomes not as responsive and sometimes freeze after this hard reset. horrible.Update #3: After using the phone for 6 months now, I realize the battery life starts to give. I am a very light phone and internet user, may be only get online for 15-30 min, and talk 30-45 min per day. The battery will last only 8-12 hours, sometimes even less. When it was new, it was at least 12 to 18 hours.Update #4: This is the 7th month of experience. The phone has become very laggy and even "temporary freeze" randomly. The message "too many cards have been open" become more frequent. I have to do restart the phone every time. Another thing is that I think the is a "bug" when receiving CJK txt messages. First, the phone doesn't support CJK (Chinese Japanes Korean) language on TXT meg. However, view CJK web site has no problem. Anyway, the main problem here is that, when any CJK txt message is reviewed. The phone will randomly restart. Until I delete those CJK message. the restarting problem is cured.

    2013-11-13: This custom case fits PERFECTLY, and looks GREAT. The fit is so snug and perfect, it actually makes my Lumia 820 seem slimmer / smaller in my pocket. The quality of material build is very good, and well worth the asking price. The case has the look and feel of something much more expensive. One small note of caution: when you decide to take the phone out, take your time and use caution. As the fit is so precise, you do need to "massage" the phone out of the case (very gently), to make sure you do not scratch or mar anything. There is no belt clip, so this case is generally intended to be used for briefcase, purse or pocket storage. I would recommend this to all Lumia 820 owners.

    2012-12-03: This screen protector is great! It went on very easily, though I have had experience putting them on before. There were literally no bubbles, except for a few that squeegeed out easily (I used my license to smooth them out, the card given is too small.) A tip for applying it: Position the protector at the top or bottom, pressing down only the edge on the top/bottom, then use a credit card, etc, to smooth the rest of the protector onto your device. It's been on my phone for about 3 weeks now, and it looks just like it does the day I put it on! If you have greasy fingers (Just ate pizza, perhaps?) the oil slick on the screen will cause a rainbow effect. This is easily wiped off with a cloth or your sleeve. Love it!

    2012-08-22: I was looking for a good anti-glare/matte finish protector for my Galaxy S III which was not overtly expensive. After reading reviews for several similar products, I finally decided to get GreatShield Ultra Anti-Glare (Matte) Clear Screen Protector Film. Honestly, I was not disappointed.The instructions were easy. I like that the film doesn't fully extend and cover the whole front of the phone, leaving a a cm of space from the edge. This is good especially to those who has a phone case cover that hugs and extends towards the front-face of the phone (like mine does). However, lining the upper film cut-outs to the phone takes a bit of time. The anti-glare/matte finish works great even under direct light. The cover has a high quality finish which doesn't impair the phone's touch screen. Price is affordable.TIPS for a lint/bubble free application:1. Use a small drop of rubbing alcohol. This dissolves any fingerprint oils & easily air drys.2. Use tweezers to hold the film.3. Apply film in a relatively dust-free room that has minimal air current.

    Rating: 5

    2012-10-16: The case came quickly, nicely packaged in retail packaging. It fits well, looks like it will do a nice amount of protection since it states it will provide shock absorbance, dust resistant (doubt that, all rubber cases attract dust) and scratch resistant, but I've had past experiences with otterbox cases for my past smartphones and all the cases I've owned did a great job. The only bad thing about this case is the installment of the case itself. The iPhone pops right into the rubber layer easily, but squeezing the phone into the hardshell case is a pain in the ass. It tells you on the directions to put the phone in the bottom first, then pushing it into the top. I've tried both ways (putting the phone in from the top and bottom) and both were really difficult to do. Once I put it in the bottom way, trying to push down on the phone so I could squeeze the top half of the phone into the top of the hard case was a pain in the ass as well. You have to literally bend the hard case over the top of the phone and try to get the lock button and headphone cover buttons into the holes without pushing the rubber part off the phone, which will happen. I've had to re-apply the case into the hard shell part numerous times, and I've finally gotten it right...I think. Another tiny problem that annoys me is the top right of the case of the phone doesn't seem "snug", it looks like the rubber part isn't fully inside the hard case. Overall, it's a great case and will do it's job but prepare for a hard time putting the hard shell case on the rubber part.

    2013-04-11: Looks terrific, protects against damage if you drop your phone. DON'T get the hybrid though. It's not the real thing and you'll be disappointed.

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-29: Most of the time my iPhone stays inside an Otterbox Defender case. However after trying out some other cases of other brands recently, that were all smaller more sleek cases, I decided to order a Otterbox Commuter case to try it out. It's significantly slimmer than the Defender, so I find it fits in my jeans pockets easier. Both the Defender and the Commuter use a 2 case design of one case fitted inside of another. The inner case of the Defender is hard plastic, with the outer case being soft rubber. The Commuter case is the opposite, having a soft case for the inside and a hard plastic case for the outside.Check to make certain when you order your case that you are getting it from Amazon themselves (might also say "Fulfilled by Amazon"), if you want to be certain you are not buying a knock off fake. While the majority of 3rd party sellers here are probably selling the genuine thing, a number of recent negative experiences many have people have posted about in their reviews sounds as though one of the sellers was shipping out fakes. Real Otterbox cases are tough, and last a long time. They don't fall apart within days. If you're buying this and able to get it shipped to you using Amazon Prime Delivery or Amazon Super Saver Delivery, you are getting it from Amazon themselves and should receive the genuine case.I ordered the Hot Pink and White case, and I find it's a little lighter in color than the online photo shows. Online the case looks almost fuschia, but in hand it's a lighter shade. It comes with a screen protector you can apply to your iPhone touch screen, and it goes on quite well. All the buttons on my phone are easily accessed when it's in this case, and there are snug gaskets over the charging port and earphone port to help your phone resist being damaged should it come in contact with water. It's a cute case and I think I'll be ordering a second one in another color. If you're looking for a little extra added protection, check out Otterbox Defender line.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-01: My Husband liked my otter box for my 5 and when he received this one for his 4 he was quit pleased. Likes the protection that it offers without the bulkiness of the Defender series otter box.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-29: Considering these retail typically at $35, this is a great value. The commuter case is nice because it is not as big as the defender series, but it still offers 2 layers of protection. It still makes the phone easy to fit in a pocket but protects it in case you drop it. The covers over the ports are nice as well as it gives the phone a little defense against moisture and the all evil pocket lent. The only complaint is that it leaves the camera wide open, but most cases do anyway.I know that prices can change based on demand, especially accessories like these that are for older model phones, but it is slightly frustrating that there can be a $10 difference. I also find it amusing that they offer "frustration free packaging" considering the packages in the stores are so frustration free that half the time in Walmart they are stolen straight out of the package.All in all, a great recommendation for any owner of this phone.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-09: I've been buying my family the Otterbox Commuters now for all their iphones. This is the 3rd one for the 4S I've purchased and I love it like the first ones I've bought. I have purchased these mostly for my wife and children who don't typically take good care of their phones. It's not as thick as the Defender series but still gives it the protection Otterbox is known for. It even looks somewhat "cool".

    Rating: 5

That case too started to chip, and so I was a little disappointed and purchased the speck case. So far the speck case hasn't cracked (knock on wood!) and seems to offer the same protection as the otterbox. But you definitely can't beat the customerservice of the otterbox!

    Rating: 4

    2012-03-04: I love this case because it is exactly what it looks like in the picture. One of my biggest pet peeves is if the picture misrepresents the product. Like so of the other reviews the only problem is that the silicone gets grungy very easily, and the polycarbonate case doesn't fit perfectly over the silicone case. No one would be able to notice though, unless they really look at it closely. This case is really easy put together.You can clean the silicone part by mixing 1/2 cup of Clorox, and water, then soak the silicone case for 1 night. You should have bright white again by morning!

    Rating: 5

    2012-06-02: I bought this for an iPhone 4 and it fits perfectly. I especially like the big cut out around the flash and camera. First case that does not distort flash pictures. The best feature is what seems like good protection (I don't drop phones to check out the protection) and very little bulk especially compared to the defender series. The mic flap works well. The flap over the power can be a bit annoying but loosens up with repeated use.What I did not like was the screen protector. Just bad. Bubbles galore and I have put on other screen protectors and none of them got near the amount of bubbles this one did. It could have been user error but I am pretty careful with getting screen protectors on. Also it doesnt feel that good to hold. Now that is a trade off as I am sure the Otter protection comes from the rigid plastic. But the plastic doesn't feel particularly good. The inner rubber case does feel good where you can grip that though.Bottomline is a good trade off for adding minimal size yet providing what seems to be good protection. It also looks nice. I would just have another brand of screen protector on hand.Update: From the department of irony. A friend wanted to see the case when we were out walking. I took the case out in a swinging motion from my front parket and it fell forward onto hard concrete with a little forward momentum. Absoultely fine. So yes the hard rigid plastic doesn't feel great, but it does serve a purpose. And although less cushion feel then the defender series that gets you less added bulk and weight.

After a year of punching through this case, I emailed Otterbox to ask them for the SKU so I could order, at my expense, the correct case for my phone. Otterbox's customer service department's response was remarkable and excellent. They acknowledged my original purchase from Amazon and sent me, at no charge, a Commuter case that fits perfectly on my Verizon Iphone 4. The Commuter case remains one of the best choices for the Iphone and Otterbox's customer service is outstanding.

    2012-05-22: I had the Otterbox Commuter with my iPhone 3GS and it was awesome (see my review about dropping it in the septic tank). It fit well and protected equally well. The silicone keeps rolling off the iPhone frame and is peeling. The plastic isn't the thick plastic I had on the 3GS but a much thinner plastic which has already cracked and broken off around the camera eye piece. The plastic also does not fit well with the silicon and fits loosely on the phone. My Griffin iPhone charge cable and some headphone jacks will not work with the Commuter 4S. The only positive aspect of this cover is the hot pink color. My husband bought the same Commuter case in a different color and has experienced the same problems, so this is an issue with design and manufacturing and not with my case alone.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-27: Some people say that the sides have excess and the corners come off. We have had no problems with the Commuter. My 7 year old uses this phone because he doesnt know that apple products are junk, regardless, OtterBox makes great products. The Commuter Series is nice and slim compared to the Defender Series

    Rating: 5

    2012-06-13: I compared many different cases before deciding on this one... It's a perfect mix of the advantages of a hard and a soft case. Hard cases are good if you like to keep your phone in a pocket- it slides in and out easily. But soft cases offer more shock protection... So a case that combines both is ideal. There are a few others out there, but this one wins because of it's simplicity and low form factor- the most protection for the least amount of bulk. My main complaint (which is pretty minor) is the unnecessary cut out for the Apple logo on the back- sure, some people may want to show off how cool they are owning an iPhone, but I really doubt most of us care or want that extra hole in the case. Otherwise, highly recommended.

    Rating: 4

    2013-09-15: Works great even if it is a bit difficult for us older folks who are all thumbs. ( : It arrived as scheduled also. Thank you!

    Rating: 4

    2014-02-19: There are three parts to the case, a screen protector, a silicone full inner case and a hard shell partial outercase.The screen protecter is fine. They include a very small cloth to clean the screen and a small plastic card to burnish the protector to you phone screen. Some brands will include a tacky strip to aid in removing small dust particles before installing a cover but OtterBox does not.The inner silicone shell is designed with a full front bezel and peel-back covers for your charging port and headphone jack. In addition your on/off switch and volumn buttons are fully covered. There is a wide opening for the camera and Apple Logo in the both the silicone case and outer hard shell.I was never able to get the hard shell fully seated on both sides of the phone. There are cut-outs on the sides of the silicone case where tabs on the hard case seat into. I could get one tab in but never both. If you don't get both sides seated the silicone frame is not snug and that part of the hard case doesn't lay flat. After removing and reinstalling the case three times I decided I don't like it well enough to hassle with it anymore.There is one other thing I don't like about the case but that is a personal preference. I don't like hard cases, I find them slippery and miss the grip I get from a TPU or all silicone case. Despite the hard case not covering the sides of the phone completely it does cover the area where you hold the phone. If you already use and like hard cases it wouldn't bother you.

    Rating: 2

    2013-02-23: I ordered this for my 4s because I love Otterbox cases, but not the price of them. This was a great price and is just the same as what you pay twice as much for at a store. Granted you have to wait to get it, but to me that is worth it to save some money!

    Rating: 5

    2012-10-03: I had the same series of case from Otter for 3GS and loved it. The only problem back then and still holds true today, is that the phone can't be in any of my charging/docking/speaker stations while the cover is on. I had previously gone through 2 Commuters (yes Otter was fantastic about replacing) as the case cracked down by the pin connector from constantly taking it out of and putting back in the case.Now with my 4S, it is the same dilemma: can't listen to music/keep it charged with case on utilizing my current docking stations. So do I keep taking it of its case, which will surely lessen the life of it or just deal with it.5 stars if they could figure out a case that maybe you could just figure that out.Has anybody had success with using this in a docking/charger/speaker station and not having to remove the case? If so, which station are you using?

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-15: This case is except able and very sleek/smooth. The anti-virus film is a little hard to put on the screen, but that could just be my husbands not so steady hand. But it is a nice black case.

Most devices you plug your phone into can't do it easily without an extension piece. I'd rather have my phone protected.

    2012-04-22: What else is there to say. This case fits my wife's iPhone 4 perfectly. I originally got her the Otterbox defender when we got our iPhone 4's. She didn't like it because she kept her phone in her purse or pocket. The rubberized finish wasn't great for pulling the phone out of her pocket. And it was definitely overkill for keeping it in her purse. So I started looking. The Commuter Series fits my wife's requirements perfectly! The smooth finish allows her to keep her phone in her pocket or purse. She loves this case. God love her, I saw her drop the phone one time on the ground and stepped on it while trying to pick it up! The phone survived. LOL. The case sacrificed itself (the top corner cracked) but I'd rather replace a 25.00 case over a 400.00 iPhone. So I have NO issues with it's ability to protect the phone.Oh, and we just have the plain iPhone 4, not the 4s. Don't let people fool you, this case fits the iPhone 4 perfectly. I'd buy this case again.

    2013-09-03: This case didn't last long. I bought into the Otterbox hype and purchased these for my and my wife's phones. Neither lasted long.     Rating: 1

    2014-02-01: Not too bulky and easily slides into a pants pocket. In fact I quit using my belt holder and just keep it in my pocket like my kids do. This case slides easily into your pocket; however, it will slide on a smooth sloped surface like a car dash. My only complaint, hence four stars, is that the rubber becomes more pliable over time. So now after 18 months of use, it does not fit snugly on my phone. So when I take it off to wipe down my phone, it takes a while to get it installed properly on my phone.To solve the sliding car dash issue, I bought a front window phone holder that I keep permanently in my truck. I am waiting for car companies to install permanent phone holders just like drink holders.

    Rating: 4

    2012-04-05: I like Otterbox and own a number of their cases. This one has some shortcomings. It's a hard case so there's little protection from drops. The case won't slide over the phone with a screen protector on as it's too snug. The case insists on sliding between the screen protector and the phone, essentially peeling off the screen protector. Finally gave up on applying a screen protector after this happened repeatedly.Also - one big shortcoming w/this case as well as the Commuter, which I three of -- somebody at Otterbox completely overlooked the fact that people like to plug in lots of different varieties of ear buds to listen to music. They must have tested this with one brand that has a really narrow pin to plug in. We have yet to find ANY earbuds that will plug into the case w/o modifying the case. I ended up having to bore out the earphone jack hole on all three of the cases so my kids can listen to music w/o completely removing the case. What a nuisance!

    Rating: 3

    2014-06-08: It was a good case but both I got ended up cracking at the bottom where the connector went in. Its kinda a small form factor case to the defender series. Which is nice. The crack doesn't really make it not work but is just disappointing.

    Rating: 5

    2012-10-06: This case comes with a screen protector, a silicon layer, and a polycarbonate layer. I love that it comes with a screen protector cause that way you don't have to buy it seperatly. The silicon layer is not really for protection, its just so the second layer doesn't ruin the phone. And then the polycarbonate is a strong layer that protects the phone very well. If you drop your phone, the screen will not crack because the case takes in all the impact. Unlike other very protective cases, this one isn't very wide which is great. It easily fits in my pocket. What I do not like though is the apple logo on the back of the phone is uncovered. It gets dirty and finger marks so I wish they covered it like in the defender series. For anyone looking for a great deal of a case that protects the phone, and still doesn't make it hard to fit in your pocket, this is definitely the best case out there and I highly recommend it.

    Rating: 5

    2012-10-17: I don't know if Otterbox will like this review, but I'm going to write it, anyway.I bought this case back in November. Everything about it has been just fine.The case is not too big, but one can definitely feel that it provides nice protection. My only complaint is that I wish they did collegiate colors.I have grown somewhat clumsy in my dotage, and have dropped my iPhone 4S a couple of times. Those drops have produced nary a scratch or crack in the glass.Well, about a month ago, the top lip of the hardshell developed a crack. I have no idea why. I kept the phone in my pants pocket, so that could explain the issue. Then, after about 3 weeks, the top hardshell lip broke completely off.I made a warranty claim with Otterbox (via their website). They sent me a couple of e-mails to confirm that I was an actual Otterbox owner, and then a few more e-mails.And then I received a brand new case in the mail today!Wow! What customer service!!!Truth be told, this is about the third time Otterbox has treated me this way. I have a couple of iPod waterproof boxes (that I swim laps with - ugh), and when those started to barely leak, Otterbox replaced them for me. Free.Highest, highest marks to Otterbox!!!

    Rating: 4

    2013-07-10: My wife bought an OtterBox case for her iPhone 4 two years ago, and she loved it. I borrowed her phone occasionally, and I enjoyed it too. It was well designed with enough padding to protect the iPhone, and the rubberized grip made it easy to hold. But after a couple of years of use and abuse, the screen cover was badly scratched, and the case was dropped one time too many and cracked. So we shopped around for another OtterBox and chose the Commuter Series case. If anything, it's an improvement over the old OtterBox. It's noticeably smaller and less bulky, and it's easier to insert the iPhone 4.All of the necessary openings are there, including the camera flash. The case has rubberized grips in the areas where your hand holds the phone. Unlike some cases we've seen, the opening for the charger plug is big enough to allow the plug to be pushed in without any difficulty. And the case looks good.Overall, the OtterBox case is an attractive case that fits the iPhone 4 perfectly and provides excellent protection for the phone.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-01: These cases offer okay protection, but at a cost. The screen protector doesn't seat completely, and it is very shiny. It's a pain to see in an office setting or outside. The case also catches a tremendous amount of dirt/grossness. It gets under the screen protector and can be felt scratching the screen under the "protector". My 4S actually had more damage from being in the case than without. The rubber protection around the hard plastic shell rips and tears easily at spots where you would open it (vibrate buttion, charging port, etc).While it did survive some nasty drops, I wish I got a Lifeproof (who was recently purchased by Otterbox). Spend the extra money and get the Lifeproof case.

    Rating: 3

    2012-01-08: After having dozens of mobile phones over the past decade, I've tried many many cases; some plastic, others leather, some pouches. I was turned on to Otterbox last year for my Blackberry, and it worked like a charm. After upgrading to an iPhone 4S, I did research online, checked many reviews, tried out cases in the store, and found the Otterbox Commuter to be the right one for me.It has a silicon inner case, with a hard plastic outer case. I prefer the hard plastic outer, since its easier to get in and out of my pocket. The rubber corners are a great trick for impact protection, although you won't find me doing drop tests off the roof of my car to the asphalt below.The clear plastic screen that came with the case was easy to apply and I can't even tell its on.My DW has been using the Otterbox Defender on her phone, which is fine for a purse person, but since my phone goes in my pants pocket, this slimmer version works for me. From a fashion perspective, it seems to project the original shape and form of the iPhone, instead of masking it behind a much larger case.The ports on this phone, from which I primarily use just the charger, are easy to access and seem to get gunk like lint out of the connector. I see myself keeping this case for the lifetime of my phone.Overall, I'm completely pleased.

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-27: Great color, and price was good. This is a flexible and durable product. It fits well to my phone. I would recommend to others.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-07: I love this case. It might not be the slimmest one around, nor the most glamorous looking but if you're a klutz, like me, it is WORTH IT! I am tall and therefore the height I drop it from is significant enough to do serious damage to the phone without a case or a flimsier case. I can attest to this because after almost two years of ownership, it has developed a small crack (the case, not the phone!) from all the dropping.I can fit it into my back pocket, it's not insanely huge and the silicone allows it to be grippier and prevent it from sliding all over smooth surfaces. It also increases the shock absorption and distribution when you drop it. A hard case can crack on impact and ruin your phone, a soft one might not be protection enough, this has both things.One thing that was kind of annoying, but something I anticipated after watching a review on youtube about this case, is that the silicone flap that over the charge port doesn't close all the way and the fact that the plastic portion might have a slightly imperfect fit over the silicone. You will get over this very quickly, it is not bothersome enough to interfere with anything. I'm pretty OCD about this stuff and I don't even notice it anymore.It is easy to take the phone in and out of the case and while for the most part your phone will be left with no marks, I DID end up having slight marks on the metal band around the phone where the volume and power buttons are. This is part of normal wear and tear, I'm not too concerned.I've dropped my phone off tables, couches, onto linoleum and cement and it's been just fine in this case. It's a worthy investment!

    Rating: 5

    2012-01-07: Practically everyone has an otterbox for their iPhone, so I figured I'd give it a shot, in hopes of protecting my brand new phone 4S. When I first got this case I was really pleased with it. It fit very nicely and also looked nice. The first drop the plastic cracked at the top corner near the ear bud jack. It did protect the phone, but the case got loose on that top corner. Then I took it off to put a screen protector on and went to put it back on and you have to bend the plastic on the case a little to get it over the top rubber buttons covering the ear bud jack and on button. I did this and the whole upper third of the case snapped off. Now i put the case on successfully two or three other times before, but this time it snapped. And looking at it the plastic is very thin and cheap, probably why it cracked the first time I dropped it. It's a nice case that looks good, but the plastic is made way too cheaply. I'd rather just be careful with my phone and get a cheaper, less bulky bumper case.

    Rating: 2

It almost fell off the table a few times.--Gel insert is a bit cheapOverall, I wanted to like this case but I just couldn't keep it. It just didn't feel comfortable in my hand.     Rating: 5

    2014-01-19: There are many Otter box's on the market, but this is probably one of the more cost effective for durability and function. The first inner layer is a robust silicone material which is durable and absorbs impact force along with the outer hard plastic layer that fits tightly. Most of the buttons: power, volume, headset input and the 30-pin plug are covered with the silicone. The camera and flash are given a wider window for easier cleaning for dust and debris and for picture clarity. One poor note - the headphone 3.5mm plug is covered with the hole on the wrong side.The feel of the otter box is a little less slippery than most and definitely less bulky. It's really just a series of thin, but tough skins over your phone. There is no doubt that you can drop this and feel protected. The hard plastic outer sheath does not completely cover your iPhone like the others. Instead it has cut-outs to give just as much protection without excessive cove rage. It's simply better designed than previous models. Check out the price on other models and you'll see that this is on the lower end, but it doesn't skimp on quality.It also comes with a separate plastic clear cover along with a cleaning cloth and an installation card for those bubbles. YOUTUBE has some great videos of how to easily apply these covers without any bubbles or trouble.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-19: I love the colors of this OtterBox, but the white part gets dirty fast. When I tried to clean it, it still looked almost gray.

    Rating: 3

    2013-01-07: it's ok with me cuz I like the real color better. This pic makes it look like a washed out, light teal.and it is NOT...it's a lovely deep teal hard shell with a lighter teal rubber. MUCH darker, but also MUCH MUCH prettier@!!!!! I was very pleased when I saw the color....and this is my total favorite out of all my speck/otterbox cases. And I have many.STUNNING color. NOT like the pic at all

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-11: This phone could be dropped anywhere and still be fine. This otter box was designed to be a skinnier than all the other otter boxes but still have great protection. It feels good in your hands and is not hard to fit in your pocket. I gave this otter box 4 stars only because it doesn't come with a built in screen protector and is easy to get scratches on the screen if dropped. So I do recommend you buy a separate screen protector and you can see it in one of my reviews. Buy this product if you drop your phone a lot!

    Rating: 4

    2013-03-10: This case fits perfectly for those like myself who prefer to carry their iPhone in their pockets. It provides a nice level of protection while still fitting in a typical uniform shirt pocket. I found the Defender case to be too thick and rubbery to permit one to easily insert and remove the iPhone from a shirt or pants pocket.There is a little design flaw with this case, hence the four star rating. The plastic frame at the bottom of the case in front of the docking port is a little too thin. After putting this in my pocket upside down for ten days, the plastic piece in front of the docking port split in half. It is just too thin to be tugged on when removing the case (and iPhone) from a pocket. The piece at the top of the cover spans the entire depth of the iPhone and doesn't seem to be prone to the same cracking. So, as long as you pull the phone out of a pocket by the top of this case, you should be fine. My Defender case now sits in my nightstand.Otterbox quickly replaced the broken case once I contacted them under their one-year warranty program.Great price and Amazon Prime is an added bonus.

    Rating: 4

    2013-07-14: I loved my case it was not what I expected it was WAY better. Will buy more from this vender! Thanks

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 2

    2013-07-29: This case is actually very good. It really fits the phone well, covers all the buttons as it should, and definitely feels secure in the event of dropping and such. The color choice SUCKS. The silicone part of the case is white and I dont think the couldve thought of a worse color. It is CONSTANTLY FILTHY. I'm not a dirty person, but I am a female that wears some makeup (as most do), so the case gets dirty from that. So unless you plan on holding the phone an inch from your face you will end up with a makeup covered case that doesnt come off. And don't even think of putting it in jeans--- it will turn blue. Pretty much anything and everything gets stuck to the white silicone and it looks disgusting. I've had this phone about 2 weeks and I've already purchased a new different one because I cannot stand the look of it. So if you dont mind a dirty case/don't wear makeup or jeans.... go ahead and get it! The quality is great besides the dirt factor!Oh and the bottom cover for the charger doesn't stay tucked under-- so that can sometimes get annoying as well.

    Rating: 2

    2012-12-04: This otter box is slim and stylish! Stands up to a seven year old boy AND slips in and out of my purse or pocket with a hard back!

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-24: I was trying to find a decent way of protecting my wife's new Iphone from the drops that all her phones in the past have died from. I decided to purchase this for based on reviews and the fact that she loves how it looks. Anything bulkier would just destroy the total appearance of the phone. My wife has been using it for about a month now and loves it. No she has not dropped the phone yet but I think that may be due to the fantastic grip you get with this cover on it. I see where some other reviewers have complained that it is not for girls because the white gets dirty right away. I have not idea what these girls are putting their phones in to get dirty so quick but has been absolutely no problem her with my wife so I guess it just depends on the person and perhaps the age to. Anyways we have been very pleased with the otterbox case and is just right.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-01: i like this case cuz the rubber is firmer than the defender , i have had a few otter box cases and this one is the best so far!!

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-26: This item is well worth the money. Very light and well protective for the screen and your phone in general, Great for the price....

    Rating: 5

    2012-01-25: The white rubber is too stiff. Takes away from the power button feel. Black rubber seems to be softer.The white gets dirty in no time.

    2013-05-11: I bought this for my daughter and she loves it! She's one to switch cases often but this one has been on for several weeks so she must like it!

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-08: Bought this case and while I like the looks, it didn't hold up to a drop. As someone else mentioned in their review the silicon piece was very flimsy. I've had other Otterbox cases and the silicon piece on this one was very weak. I'm usually very careful with my phone but I was holding my phone and something else in my hand one day and my son grabbed that other thing out of my hand and there went my phone on the floor. It fell from a distance of MAYBE 3.5 feet on to a wood floor and the plastic around the camera piece cracked and the whole corner cracked. My phone was ok but the case was not. I guess I would have expected the case to survive a drop of 3.5 feet seeing how their website says it's "Impact Resistant". I did keep the silicon piece and used it inside of another Otterbox plastic housing but it was too big/loose and the other plastic housing couldn't quite fit around it. So...take that for what you will. Leads me to believe it's not an authentic OtterBox. But I'm not an expert and that's just my opinion

    Rating: 3

    2013-01-26: I really dig this case. I originally considered an Otterbox Defender, but after comparing Defender and Commuter cases in the store, it looks like the Defender is about 1/8 to 3/16" bigger in every dimension, including thickness. I wanted it protected, but I didn't want it in a bubble. Also, my wife as a 3GS defender, and the rainbow effect on the screen was unattractive.So I instead went with the commuter and a Zagg invisibleSHIELD case-friendly screen protector. Let's just talk about the Otterbox, though:The silicone portion is not the gummy/sticky kind. It's got a bit of rigidity to it, fits the phone correctly, and covers the charge port and headphone jack that flip back for easy access. The silent/ring switch is exposed. Volume/power buttons are covered and there are tactile bumps on their place. The cameras (front and back) and home button are all totally exposed, which you can see in the pictures. Also, a cut-out for the Apple logo is (amusingly) on the back as well so you can tell it's not one of those evil Android devices I've read about (I kid).It would have been nice if the volume + and - buttons were labeled, but up is above down. Not a huge deal. I find the sleep/power button difficult to press. There's a lot of "give" to that button that wasn't there previously. I took the phone back out of the case to make sure I hadn't broken the button or something (I hadn't). Again, you get used to it and it's not a huge deal. You learn to apply more pressure and just press on one side of the button instead of the middle.The outer plastic part is slick. Literally. I picked the phone up for the first time and it immediately slipped out of my hands and landed on the carpeted floor. Easy to slide in and out of your pocket, but I wish it had a soft-touch texture or something on the sides to make it more of a sure thing to hold.It's kind of like an inside-out Defender, as the soft silicone is on the inside and the hard plastic is on the outside. The Defender, as noted above, is silicone on the outside.Still, despite all my complaints, I feel that my phone is protected and secure without feeling super-big and bulky. It adds maybe 3mm in each dimension (height, width, depth). If you need less thickness, I'd argue that you are not really protecting your phone. If you want more thickness, the Defender is there for you.

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-03: The case is great although it does not come with a screen protector or in a brand new case but it works great and is in awesome condition. I love it and it is easy on and easy off with out feeling like it will break. Very Happy

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-12: I really liked this when I first got it but it already cracked at the bottom. So I was disappointed because I thought the otter box was supposed to be durable. I might be able to super glue it and still get it to work.

    Rating: 2

    2012-04-20: I bought this case for my iPhone 4 to fix the flash problems that I have with my other cases. I do have a speck candyshell case that I like and fits well and does also have the larger cutout for the camera and flash but it does not cover all the ports. I found that during my sons little league games dust gets in these areas so I bought this case.While I like the look and feel of the case I find that the fit isn't great. The polycarbonate shell does not fit correctly in the cutouts in the rubber. This causes a problem for the cover for the charging port. I have to try to bend the polycarbonate piece so that the cover will stay. It works ok, but definitely doesn't look as good as it does on the video review I watched on otter box.I have a couple of the otterbox defenders for the iPhone 4. While they fit well, they cause a haze in the flash and the rubber outer layer has stretched out and I always struggle to get the cover for the charging port to stay put.I like that the commuter is easy to get in and out of my pocket like the speck candyshell does and there isn't a lot of added bulk. The defender is a struggle to get in and out of your poket. You do loose the grip created by the rubber outer layer on the defender. The outer layer on the commuter is pretty slick. It would be nice if it had a bit of grip.Overall, I'm pretty happy with this case, but I wish that it fit better. I hope that my solution to getting the charging cover to stay put lasts...Update: after just a couple of days the outer shell of this case cracked. I contacted Otterbox and they responded immediately. I provided a little information to them and they are sending me a replacement. Excellent customer service!!!

    Rating: 3

I don't do much outside, or get dirty so I am highly confused as to why it's changed. Have now retired the case after only 2 weeks. But the case itself, is a good case, just poor color choice I suppose.

    2012-09-10: I really like Otterbox cases. This one is my second one and it has serve it purpose on maintaining protected from dirt and hard falls. Thanks!

    Rating: 5

    2012-05-26: I really like this product. I originally bought one that was sturdier as I was so concerned about dropping my new iphone. The sturdier one is great and very protective but bulky and heavy so I decided to try this one and I love it. I haven't dropped my phone but I feel the product would prevent serious damage to the phone. I did add a screen shield and I'm very happy I did that to protect the screen. If you really want to give your phone the most protection then the sturdier cover is the one you would want as it completely encloses the phone inside the case and no need for a screen protector since it's built into the case. But if you want a good cover that's less bulky this one is the way to go.Also, this brand is not that easy to find in the retail stores and the selection is very limited. The salesperson at the Apple store recommended this brand but they don't carry it. Go figure.

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-01: This is my first time buying a non Defender style OtterBox. It's certainly worth the money here on Amazon. My only complaint is that the rubberized parts of the case sometimes get out of place on the face of the phone. I'll most likely opt for the Defender series again once this case runs its course.

    Rating: 4

    2012-01-15: I have had an iPhone for about 3 years now and have gone through so many cases. I've had the iFrogz Luxe Case, SwitchEasy CapsuleRebel M Menace Hybrid Case, and the Agent18 EcoShield Slider; my boyfriend also had the Otterbox Defender. Although each of these cases has perks, they all have drawbacks. I see many more pros with the Commuter Series from OtterBox than I have seen with any other iPhone case.For starters, the case is not bulky. When comparing it to the Defender, it wins hands down. The defender was awkward, bulky, and came with a holster clip that most girls won't use. Yes, this case would be handy if you were possibly in the construction business or if you really had a problem with dropping your phone, but for my needs, it didn't fit the bill. The Commuter case has a soft inside and a hard exterior, and they come in two different colors. This is both appealing and functional. The soft rubber casing allows for a no-slip grip and shock absorber and the hard shell keeps it from being too sticky. It is comfortable in the hand and provides the perfect balance of rubber to hard shell casing.I have dropped my phone a few times and the case has held up well, I can't see any wear on it. However, I have noticed that the soft shell (my color is yellow) does show discoloration. My hard shell is gray and you can see gray spots all throughout my yellow case. While this is not a big deal to me, it is just something I thought was worth mentioning. The Commuter Series in my opinion is superior to all other iPhone cases I have owned and, for $22, I think it's worthy of protecting the iPhone.

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-30: My mom LOVES her otterbox. It looks nice and the colors are perfect for her. The only downfall, which is kinda important, is the white softer portion is already discoloring (from absorbing the dirt from our hands). This is an awesome case, and I highly recommend an otterbox, it doesn't add much bulk, keeps the headphone and charging ports protected from dust, but keep the coloring in mind when ordering (mom got the purple/white one if it doesn't say that anywhere, I ordered the blue with a lighter blue softer shell, mine is showing discoloring too, but less noticeable because its not white). I definitely recommend the case, just make sure you think about your coloring!

    Rating: 3

    2013-08-18: If you know anything about the Otterbox cases, is that they are generally ugly. I am thinking that they received reviews and noticed this too as they are now coming out with more attractive and less bulkier cases with the same protection. This case is awesome, it has great protection, isn't as bulky, and looks nice.

    Rating: 5

    2012-03-18: I got the Commuter Otterbox case the day before my new iPhone 4s came. I've been debating for a few days on whether to get the Defender or the Commuter and after doing some research, I have decided to get the Commuter. The Defender is nice and seems super durable, but honestly I do not drop my phone that often and I am usually good with my phones, except for the occasional accidents I drop it every once in awhile. Also, the Defender is too bulky for my taste. One reason I got the iPhone was for its sleekness and the Defender would have ruined that feature for me. Since I do not want to compromise the sleekness of the phone, but also want great protection and knowing I take good care of my phones, the Commuter seemed like a good compromise.I will admit, putting on the case took a bit of effort first. You definitely have to "massage" the phone in the case a little since you are trying to make it line up with all the buttons/switches with the silicone case and the hard plastic cover. I am a perfectionist so when I saw that it was not lining up correctly, I kept fidgeting with it or took the phone out and tried it all over again. The trick is to slide the bottom part in first and then press on the top part to snap it into place (just like the video on otterbox.com) Before I was doing the opposite so I felt kind of dumb that I did not just look at the video first (haha). I can reach all of the buttons and switches fine and the flaps for the usb/charger connector and the headphones stay in place when I tuck them in. I can see some people with big fingers having trouble trying to switch the silence on/off, so keep that in mind if it is a big deal for you.I am not really sure why some reviewers said their case is not lining up correctly with their phone or the phone just does not fit with the case. I am looking at my phone with the case on and it is all secure and tight. I do not have the screen protector that came with it on, but I am sure I will need to soon so I do not regret it later.Like I said before, if you're clumsy, just get the Defender and you will not have to worry about your phone at all. If you are usually mindful with your phone, get the Commuter. I have not dropped my phone on concrete or anything like that yet (fingers crossed!) but if I do end up letting it happen, I will update!UPDATE!Ok, so I've had this case for a little over a month and my iPhone is still sitting pretty in it. I just dropped my phone today on tile when it slipped out of my hands because I was fiddling around with my handbag. Oh my god was I happy that nothing happened to my phone or case! I still say this case is a great buy, I mean 20 bucks to protect a $200 phone is pretty nice! I'm never letting this phone out of its case when I'm out. If it wasn't for this case, my phone will be shattered!Only negatives about this case is it takes a bit to get the phone to fit in the case, but you get used to it after a few times. Also, the lock/unlock button and volume buttons are somewhat hard to press down easily since the silicone covers them, but you get used to that as well.Happy hunting for the right case everyone!

    Rating: 4

    2012-03-19: This is a wonderful case. Just what I was looking for. It's a 2 piece system. A high quality siliconized rubber(not the sticky lint collector type) fits tight around your phone but still lets everything function properly. Then a plastic shield clamps around the top, bottow and sides but still lets the rubber show in the corners. This allows great grip with slippery fingers. The whole thing is low profile and slides in my pocket with ease. Great fit and function and plenty of quality to last up to abuse. I would recomend this to anyone who wants a thin case that works with pockets and still protects the phone. As always Amazon had the best price with free shipping.

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-10: I used to use a different type of case (Speck Candyshell), although similar to the OB commuter case, but switched to Otterbox for no real reason. While using this otterbox case, I placed my phone on top of my Mustang's roof and took off down the road (absent minded mom). The phone flipped off the roof and landed in the street and was run over by the other cars behind me. I watched the rear view window in horror as it jumped off the pavement as each car went over it. There was not a scratch on my iPhone. I kid not. It only powered itself down. The case was smashed a little but still usable. I emailed otterbox to tell them about his amazing story and they simply wanted to replace the case for me for free. ???? Seriously? Saved my phone AND a free replacement? So I get a new case and SURE enough, I did it again. Again, it was run over several times (same busy street). This time, tire marks on the front of the case, and pavement pits on the back. Still, my iPhone was unharmed. Just powered itself down. I just bought another OB case to replace my cracked case - Otterbox would have replaced it again, but seriously, I'll gladly buy another from them. This case has saved me so much money and headaches!!

    Rating: 1

    2013-12-17: The headline says it all. Great case, great priceA great protective slimline case for my iPhone. Name brand quality with Amazon pricing.

    2013-06-27: I love these cases they are durable and I drop my phones way to often and it holds up well however after like 6-8 months some of the rubber parts start to fall apart but if you go onto otterbox web site it has a section where you can upload pics of the case falling apart and they will send you out another case

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-27: When I bought my iPhone two years ago I purchased the Otterbox defender case to protect it. Although the defender case provides great protection, it has flaws; so when it was time to replace it I decided to purchase this commuter series case.Although this case does not provide the same level of protection as the defender series case, I believe it is adequate for most, and excels in areas that the defender falls short. This case is slimmer and better looking (in my opinion), it's not a lent magnet (the defender is), and the hard plastic exterior allows it to slid in and out of your pocket easily (I huge plus for me).The biggest draw back is that the buttons that are covered by the case sleep/power button and volume up/down are very difficult to press with this case on. My hope is that it will become easier as it is broken in. Also the screen protector that was included with mine did not go on very well. It does appear to be a good quality screen protector and is easy to install, but the top portion (above the front facing camera) will not stick down properly, as if it does not have adhesive on that area. I don't think this is a design flaw, I think I just got a bad one.So overall I'm happy with the protection and the look of the case, but only time will tell if the buttons function better after break in. If they do, great! if not I can live with it.

    Rating: 3

    2013-10-30: Hey this otterbox case is good. So good in fact that it did exactly what it said that it would do. This case is made in China. A little overpriced but thats normal for a name brand.

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-08: Really heavy duty case, a bit bulky but it serves its purpose. Very sturdy and protects the entire phone excluding the front. I use this case whenever i'm going outdoors for protracted periods.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-20: We've bought many OBs over the years, and when my 16-yo needed a new flavor, she picked this nice green one. The texture seems like it has changed, and I really like the feel of this version. It fits tight, but not impossible.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-18: I really like this case. It does exactly what it claims to do and that goes a long way! Easy to handle and won't stick inside pockets. When the case cracked prior to the 1 year warranty expiring, I simply took pictures proving the damage claim and OtterBox sent a new case out almost immediately. Since the case comes with a protective film for the screen, I was able to completely change out my case and start new again. So rest assured, that even if this case fails (which it shouldn't), you have solid customer service and support, which is another thing they claim, but it's true!Be advised though, the protective film that comes with this case is extremely reflective, but it yields the clearest/cleanest screen when in appropriate lighting. Outside, forget it, you're going to have problems, but it's still very protective and fits just fine.

    Rating: 5

    2011-12-13: I am obsessed with babying my iPhone 4S, but didn't want an overly bulky case. After reading all the positive reviews and YouTube videos I decided on this one. It didn't come at a blazing speed but I didn't bother getting mad at that.-First impressions were that it was easy to install but was bulkier than advertised but not by too much. Just don't think it's going to retain a sleek look. Was pretty happy with it until I realized it won't fit in a dock at all and the headphones won't go in. Was still not going to freak out cause I figured it was the price to pay for protecting my awesome phone.-Fast forward a couple weeks. Found a few new annoyances. 1)The snap in protector for the charging slot won't stay in. 2) The lip on the side gets in the way in landscape mode when texting/gaming (kind of). 3) when I pulled off the case I realized that the silicone is letting in (and trapping) all kinds of dirt and grime. Now I pull it off every couple of days and soak the case in soapy water for a while. Also it just looks like a redneck or a child's case compared to how everyone else has their phone.- So to wrap it up finally.. Unless all you're after is paranoia protection and nothing else, show off your phone a little more and get a wrap and bumper or slim case. Apple is a much better designer than otterbox and it'll get just as dirty with or without it. Btw, the good thing about the case is that it DOES FIT THE 4S, and looks like it would actually help if dropped but I don't know from experience ....

It offers plenty of protection against drops, is somewhat water resistant (not totally submergible, but will hold up if you spill a drink on it), and is easy to install.     2014-02-26: I don't like cases for my iPhone. I think they all take away from the sleek looks of an expensive phone. I haven't found any case that improves the look of my phone. But, it's difficult to rationalize the feeling when you drop your phone and you know it's going to shatter. In that brief moment in time, your pulse quickens and your BP rises. You break out in a sweat and you remember having looked at cases and thinking, "I'll just be extra careful," knowing quite well that you really should have used protection....All this takes place in one or two seconds. And then reality hits: You pick up the phone and see the glass. It's like having your puppy run over by a car...sickening. So you spend a hundred dollars or so to get your screen replaced, and the same day you pick out a durable case like you should have done in the beginning. Do yourself a favor and buy this case before it's too late. The Otterbox Commuter will not improve your phone's looks but it isn't as clunky and the Defender series. You need it, you know it, now buy it .

    Rating: 4

The new glass if almost unscratchable anyway. Because of the loosening of the case, I switched to the Otterbox Defender and am liking that much more, despite the slightly more bulky size.
